{"uri": "2024-07-424692273", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-17", "time": "11:04:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-17T11:04:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-17T04:06:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://411mania.com/wrestling/ted-dibiase-collaboration-success-hulk-hogan/", "title": "Ted DiBiase Thinks It Was A Collaboration Behind The Success Of Hulk Hogan", "body": "On the latest episode of Everybody's Got a Pod, WWE Hall of Famer Ted DiBiase talked about WWE signing talent from other promotions, such as Hulk Hogan, and his belief that it was a collaboration between Vince McMahon and Hogan who made the character over. You can check out some highlights below:\n\nOn WWE signing talent from other promotions, such as Hulk Hogan: \"The thing you got to remember is Vince McMahon, he didn't just go steal the talent. He had conversations with promoters and said, 'Hey, this is what I'm about to do. If you want to come on board and be a part of it, then please do.' But none of them did, because they all were -- you know, those wrestling promoters own their territory. And, 'By God, you're not gonna come in here.' You don't have enough sense to look down the road and see what's happened and where it's going? And what you could be a part of? It's more important for them to say, 'It's just mine. You can't have it.\"\n\nOn McMahon changing the business: \"I'll be honest with you. Because I grew up in the business? At first, when I first heard about McMahon and what he was doing, I was mad. I was like, What's he doing? What the hell's he thinking he's doing?' My attitude changed pretty quick, because I thought what was coming.\"\n\nOn whether McMahon made Hogan: \"I think Vince would have to have the foresight to see, 'Okay. I can take this guy, and I can make him the centerpiece of what I'm doing.' Because let's go back to -- remember the first time I went to New York? Well, my last match in New York on my first run-through was with Hulk Hogan, before he was Hulk Hogan. And I had Hulk's first match in Madison Square Garden. And put him over.\"\n\nOn whether McMahon made Hogan because of his position: \"Well no, I mean, not exactly. I mean, positioning is important, but you got to have something to offer. Now we're looking at the other thing, the change and seeing the way -- back then, I was thinking old school sometimes too. And old school, well you know what? Vince McMahon is thinking about, 'I want my top guy to be a hero. Because I plan on down the road, getting with a toy company, and make action figures, video games'... I agree with that to a degree [McMahon making Hogan]. I mean, it's kind of like you're gonna push it down their throat. But the guy's got to have something to offer. And Hulk had his thing, and he lived up to it.... the other guy that he tried it with, and it failed miserably, was the Ultimate Warrior. {"uri": "8230152658", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-17", "time": "14:14:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-17T14:14:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-17T14:13:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.ewrestlingnews.com/news/wwe/ted-dibiase-sr-explains-the-reason-behind-hulk-hogans-success", "title": "Ted DiBiase Sr. Explains The Reason Behind Hulk Hogan's Success", "body": "The Latest On CM Punk's WWE In-Ring Return + Kevin Nash Praises Punk\n\nOn a recent edition of the \"Everybody's Got a Pod\" podcast, WWE Hall of Famer Ted DiBiase Sr. discussed WWE's recruitment of talent from other rival organizations, citing Hulk Hogan as an example.\n\nDiBiase Sr. stated that the transformation of Hogan's character was a collaborative effort between Vince McMahon and Hogan.\n\nYou can check out some highlights from the podcast below:\n\nOn WWE signing talent from other promotions, such as Hulk Hogan: \"The thing you got to remember is Vince McMahon, he didn't just go steal the talent. He had conversations with promoters and said, 'Hey, this is what I'm about to do. If you want to come on board and be a part of it, then please do.' But none of them did, because they all were -- you know, those wrestling promoters own their territory. And, 'By God, you're not gonna come in here.' You don't have enough sense to look down the road and see what's happened and where it's going? And what you could be a part of? It's more important for them to say, 'It's just mine. You can't have it.\"\n\nOn McMahon changing the business: \"I'll be honest with you. Because I grew up in the business? At first, when I first heard about McMahon and what he was doing, I was mad. I was like, What's he doing? What the hell's he thinking he's doing?' My attitude changed pretty quick, because I thought what was coming.\"\n\nOn whether McMahon made Hogan: \"I think Vince would have to have the foresight to see, 'Okay. I can take this guy, and I can make him the centerpiece of what I'm doing.' Because let's go back to -- remember the first time I went to New York? Well, my last match in New York on my first run-through was with Hulk Hogan, before he was Hulk Hogan. And I had Hulk's first match in Madison Square Garden. And put him over.\"\n\nOn whether McMahon made Hogan because of his position: \"Well no, I mean, not exactly. I mean, positioning is important, but you got to have something to offer. Now we're looking at the other thing, the change and seeing the way -- back then, I was thinking old school sometimes too. And old school, well you know what? Vince McMahon is thinking about, 'I want my top guy to be a hero. Because I plan on down the road, getting with a toy company, and make action figures, video games'... I agree with that to a degree [McMahon making Hogan]. I mean, it's kind of like you're gonna push it down their throat. But the guy's got to have something to offer. And Hulk had his thing, and he lived up to it.... the other guy that he tried it with, and it failed miserably, was the Ultimate Warrior. Trump is expected to speak Thursday night.\n\nThe Republican National Convention is stacked with a lineup of celebrity speakers, including former professional wrestler Hulk Hogan.\n\nThe WWE Hall of Fame star, 70, is set to take the stage to speak ahead of former President Donald Trump on the final night of the convention, where Trump is expected to officially accept the Republican nomination for president. Other speakers include Eric Trump, Tucker Carlson and Dana White, the head of the UFC.\n\nHere's what we know about Hulk Hogan and his upcoming speech.\n\nWho is Hulk Hogan?\n\nBorn Terry Gene Bollea in Augusta, Georgia, Hulk Hogan is one of the most well-known professional wrestlers of all time.\n\nAccording to Pro Wrestling Wiki, Hogan is a 12-time World Champion, including six WWF/WWE championships, six WCW World Heavyweight Championships, and is a former WWE World Tag Team Champion with fellow wrestler Edge.\n\nWhat time is Hulk Hogan speaking tonight?\n\nHogan is expected to speak between 7:30 pm and 8 p.m. CT. Major networks like MSNBC, Fox and CNN will air the speech. See below for a breakdown of how to watch it.\n\nIs Hulk Hogan a Republican?\n\nHogan is a registered Republican and has shared some of his voting history (supporting Obama in 2008 and Romney in 2012) and even declared his potential aspirations for running for office.\n\nAccording to The Hill, he said if he ever ran, he would run as a Republican, but at the moment, he doesn't have any plans to actually run for president.\n\n\"I've thought about it -- as of late, people [are] calling my phone, driving me crazy about running for Senate. They want me to run for governor, they want me to run for mayor,\" the former professional wrestling star told TMZ.\n\nHow are Hulk Hogan and Donald Trump connected?\n\nAccording to the Asbury Park Press, this won't be the first time Trump and the controversial pro wrestling star are teaming up.\n\nHogan competed at WrestleMania IV and V, which were both held at Trump's Taj Mahal. Those events were held in 1988 and 1989. They're also both in the WWE Hall of Fame.\n\nWho is Hulk Hogan's wife?\n\nHulk Hogan has been married to his wife, Sky Daily Hogan, a yoga instructor, since September 2023, according to People. It's the third marriage for Hulk.\n\nWho are Hulk Hogan's children?\n\nHulk Hogan has two children -- 33-year-old son Nick and 36-year-old daughter Brooke.\n\nHere's a breakdown of the major networks Vance and embracing members of his family off stage at the Republican National Convention (RNC) in Milwaukee on Monday.\n\nProfessional wrestler and Florida man Hulk Hogan will speak tonight at the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee, according to reports from NBC.\n\nHogan, 70, is set to speak ahead of Donald Trump during the final day of the convention. The former president is expected to formally accept the Republican nomination for November's presidential election tonight as well.\n\nWho is Hulk Hogan?\n\nBorn Terry Gene Bollea in Augusta, Georgia, Hulk Hogan is one of the greatest -- certainly one of the most attention-getting -- professional wrestlers of all time.\n\n\"The key figure in WWE's rise from regional attraction to worldwide entertainment leader in the 1980s, The Hulkster's superhuman size and undeniable charisma set the standard for what a Superstar should be,\" WWE writes in Hogan's biography. \"A larger-than-life icon, he packed 93,173 WWE fans into the Pontiac Silverdome, won six WWE Championships, starred in movies, television shows and his own animated series and became an idol to a vast legion of fans he dubbed his Hulkamaniacs.\"\n\nAccording to Pro Wrestling Wiki, Hogan is a 12-time World Champion, including six WWF/WWE championships, six WCW World Heavyweight championships, and is a former WWE World Tag Team Champion with fellow wrestler Edge.\n\nIs Hulk Hogan retired from wrestling?\n\nAfter a 35-year career, Hogan officially retired from wrestling in 2012.\n\nIs Hulk Hogan a Republican?\n\nHogan is a registered Republican and has shared some of his voting history (supporting Obama in 2008 and Romney in 2012) and even declared his potential aspirations for running for office.\n\nAccording to The Hill, he said if he ever ran, he would run as a Republican but at the moment, he doesn't have any plans to actually run for president.\n\n\"I've thought about it -- as of late, people calling my phone, driving me crazy about running for Senate. They want me to run for governor, they want me to run for mayor,\" the former professional wrestling star told TMZ's Harvey Levin\n\nHow are Hulk Hogan and Donald Trump connected?\n\nAccording to the Ashbury Park Press, this won't be the first time Trump and the controversial pro wrestling star are teaming up.\n\nHogan competed at Wrestlemania IV and V, which were both held at Trump's Taj Mahal. Those events were held in 1988 and 1989. They're also both part of the WWE Hall of Fame.\n\nDoes Hulk Hogan live in Florida? Wrestler has restaurant in Clearwater Beach\n\nHe also owns \"Hogan's Hangout,\" a casual restaurant that has \"become a Clearwater Beach institution, brother.\"\n\nLast year, Hogan was baptized at Indian Rocks Baptist Church in Largo with his third wife, Sky.\n\n\"Total surrender and dedication to Jesus is the greatest day of my life. No worries, no hate, no judgment... only love,\" he wrote on Instagram.\n\nUSA TODAY will provide livestream coverage on YouTube each night of the RNC, Monday through Thursday.\n\nEach television network will handle coverage slightly differently. and I'm proud to support my hero as the next President of the United States,\" Hogan said.\n\nHogan explained that he was compelled to speak at the RNC after Trump's assassination attempt.\n\nHogan joined multiple notable figures in the world of fighting including, former WWE Chairman Vince McMahon's wife Linda McMahon, and later CEO of the Ultimate Fighting Championship, Dana White.\n\nThe wrestler has been a longtime supporter of Trump, telling TMZ in 2015 that he wanted to be his running mate.\n\nWhen asked which presidential candidate he would fight, Hogan responded, \"I don't want to be in the ring with any candidates. I want to be Trump's running mate.\"\n\nFollowing the assassination attempt on Trump on July 13, Hogan shared a photo from the rally and expressed his political beliefs in a caption on Instagram.\n\n\"No President, past or present, should face such a horrific act,\" he wrote.\n\n\"Our thoughts and prayers are with President Trump, law enforcement and the Secret Service who bravely protect and uphold our shared values.\"\n\nIn an interview on Fox News ahead of tonight's event, Hogan told anchor Bret Baier that he felt compelled to speak after the assassination attempt.\n\n\"When they took a shot at my hero Donald Trump I realized I could not be silent anymore,\" he said.\n\n\"It rattled me to my core.\"\n\nWhen asked what his speech would entail, he responded, \"It's going to that he's thought about running for office \"several times.\"\n\nHogan has seemed to shift his political viewpoints, having previously endorsed Barack Obama for president.\n\nTrump has had a long history with WWE and was a close friend of Vince McMahon.\n\nMcMahon resigned from the WWE earlier this year due to allegations of sex trafficking and sexual assault.\n\nTrump first started appearing in WWE broadcasts in the 1980s but became a part of the show's plot in the late 2000s.\n\nHe and McMahon acted out a feud on WWE's Monday Night Raw that climaxed at WrestleMania 23 when Trump shaved {"uri": "8231994039", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "14:56:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T14:56:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T14:55:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.wrestlezone.com/news/1489654-hulk-hogan-is-set-to-speak-at-rnc-convention", "title": "Hulk Hogan Is Set To Speak At RNC Convention", "body": "Hulk Hogan will speak at the Republican National Committee convention on Thursday.\n\nThe WWE Hall of Famer has never been shy when discussing politics. Hulk Hogan has attempted to run for president in the past, announcing his intentions all the way back in 1998.\n\nHe talked about the possibility of running as recently as last month. The Hulkster teased a run at the presidency and ruling \"with an iron fist\" during an appearance on \"Fox & Friends,\".\n\nHis political career is set to continue later today. MSNBC reported that Hulk Hogan will speak at the Republican National Committee Convention. He will make a speech ahead of fellow WWE Hall of Famer Donald Trump accepting the GOP nomination for President of the United States.\n\n\"Two senior campaign officials confirmed to NBC News that Hulk Hogan will speak tonight at the RNC convention, ahead of former President Trump formally accepting the GOP nomination for President of the United States,\" MSNBC Tweeted out.\n\nPOST Wrestling's John Pollock also revealed that as well as the WWE Hall of Famer, Linda McMahon and UFC boss Dana White will also speak at the conference. attempt", "body": "Hulk Hogan to warm up crowd for Trump's first speech since assassination attempt\n\nVerity Bowman\n\n18 July 2024 at 6:44 pm\n\nWrestling icon Hulk Hogan will warm-up the crowd before Donald Trump formally accepts the Republican Party's nomination for president.\n\nHe will join a fight-themed speaking line-up on the final day of the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee that also includes Dana White, CEO of Ultimate Fighting Championship and Linda McMahon, former CEO of WWE, the professional wrestling promotion company.\n\nEarlier this week, Republican senator Byron Donalds referenced the WWE star when he said delegates should expect Trump's entrance on Thursday to look like \"Hulk Hogan at WrestleMania\".\n\nThe 70-year-old, who captivated millions of wrestling fans worldwide at the peak of his career in the 1980s and early 1990s, has often spoken of his interest in presidential politics.\n\n\"We need somebody in there that's got some common sense, you know what I'm saying?\" Mr Hogan, 70, told Fox & Friends last month. \"So if you need a president or a vice president, I'll volunteer and take this country over, and I'll rule with an iron fist.\"\n\nMr Hogan is also a longstanding Trump supporter who recently joined the chorus of condemnation over the attempted assassination of the former president.\n\nPreviously, he backed then Democrat presidential hopeful Barack Obama in 2008 but switched to Mitt Romney, his Republican opponent, in 2012.\n\nBeyond the ring, Mr Hogan has been involved in a string of high-profile controversies.\n\nDuring the early 1990s, he was implicated in a federal investigation into steroid distribution by WWE.\n\nIn 1991, he admitted on the Arsenio Hall Show to using steroids for medical purposes but denied using them to enhance his wrestling performance.\n\nIn 2015, a video made public by The National Enquirer revealed Mr Hogan making controversial remarks, including using a racial slur while discussing his daughter's partner.\n\nIn the video, recorded in 2007, Mr Hogan said: \"I guess we're all a little racist.\"\n\nWWE terminated Mr Hogan's contract and removed references to him from their website and Hall of Fame, but he was reinstated in 2018 after the company said he deserved a \"second chance\".\n\nIn 2012, a sex tape featuring Mr Hogan and Heather Clem, the wife of his friend Bubba the Love Sponge, was leaked, with Gawker Media publishing a portion of it.\n\nMr Hogan sued Gawker for invasion of privacy, leading to a highly publicised trial.\n\nIn 2016, Mr Hogan speech since assassination attempt", "body": "Wrestling icon will appear on final day of Republican National Convention as Donald Trump formally accepts party's nomination for president\n\nWrestling icon Hulk Hogan will warm-up the crowd before Donald Trump formally accepts the Republican Party's nomination for president.\n\nHe will join a fight-themed speaking line-up on the final day of the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee that also includes Dana White, CEO of Ultimate Fighting Championship and Linda McMahon, former CEO of WWE, the professional wrestling promotion company.\n\nEarlier this week, Republican senator Byron Donalds referenced the WWE star when he said delegates should expect Trump's entrance on Thursday to look like \"Hulk Hogan at WrestleMania\".\n\nThe 70-year-old, who captivated millions of wrestling fans worldwide at the peak of his career in the 1980s and early 1990s, has often spoken of his interest in presidential politics.\n\n\"We need somebody in there that's got some common sense, you know what I'm saying?\" Mr Hogan, 70, told Fox & Friends last month. \"So if you need a president or a vice president, I'll volunteer and take this country over, and I'll rule with an iron fist.\"\n\nMr Hogan is also a longstanding Trump supporter who recently joined the chorus of condemnation over the attempted assassination of the former president.\n\nPreviously, he backed then Democrat presidential hopeful Barack Obama in 2008 but switched to Mitt Romney, his Republican opponent, in 2012.\n\nBeyond the ring, Mr Hogan has been involved in a string of high-profile controversies.\n\nDuring the early 1990s, he was implicated in a federal investigation into steroid distribution by WWE.\n\nIn 1991, he admitted on the Arsenio Hall Show to using steroids for medical purposes but denied using them to enhance his wrestling performance.\n\nIn 2015, a video made public by The National Enquirer revealed Mr Hogan making controversial remarks, including using a racial slur while discussing his daughter's partner.\n\nIn the video, recorded in 2007, Mr Hogan said: \"I guess we're all a little racist.\"\n\nWWE terminated Mr Hogan's contract and removed references to him from their website and Hall of Fame, but he was reinstated in 2018 after the company said he deserved a \"second chance\".\n\nIn 2012, a sex tape featuring Mr Hogan and Heather Clem, the wife of his friend Bubba the Love Sponge, was leaked, with Gawker Media publishing a portion of it.\n\nMr Hogan sued Gawker for invasion of privacy, leading to a highly publicised trial.\n\nIn 2016, Mr Hogan won the lawsuit, resulting in a $140 million (\u00a3107 million) judgment against Gawker, which led to the company's {"uri": "2024-07-427257983", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "14:20:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T14:20:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T13:16:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.khq.com/lifestyles/entertainment/hulk-hogan-rips-off-his-shirt-at-republican-national-convention-viewers-react/article_10c42e11-c588-514d-add2-ed77249cc65d.html", "title": "Hulk Hogan Rips Off His Shirt at Republican National Convention  --  Viewers React", "body": "As the world of politics and the theatrical world of professional wrestling continues to blur, it only made sense that Hulk Hogan would be asked to make a speech at the Republican National Convention.\n\nThe former pro-wrestler and WWE Hall of Famer, who just last month said he hadn't yet decided whom he would support in this year's election, spoke ahead of former president Donald Trump at Thursday's (July 18) Republican National Convention in Milwaukee, Wisconsin.\n\nDressed in a red bandanna, a navy blazer, and a black \"Real American\" vest, Hogan told the crowd, \"As an entertainer, I try to stay out of politics. But after everything that's happened to our country over the past four years and everything that happened last weekend, I can no longer stay silent.\"\n\nThen, in a fired-up wrestling-style promo, Hogan removed his suit jacket and said, \"But what happened last week, when they took a shot at my hero, and they tried to kill the next president of the United States, enough was enough!\"\n\nHe then ripped off his vest to reveal a red Trump-Vance tank top underneath. \"Let Trump-a-mania run wild, brother. Let Trump-a-mania rule again. Let Trump-a-mania make America great again,\" he continued as the crowd erupted in cheers.\n\nTrump was seen raising his fist in the air in reaction to Hogan's speech, and he even blew him a kiss. Of course, the Republican presidential candidate is no stranger to wrestling; he is also a member of the WWE Hall of Fame and famously appeared at WrestleMania 23, where he took a Stone Cold Stunner from Steve Austin.\n\nTrump blowing Hulk Hogan a kiss is one of the greatest 10 seconds ever pic.twitter.com/FandUXf56C -- meme bastard (@mask_bastard) July 19, 2024\n\nOnline reactions to Hogan's speech ranged from ridicule to shock that this was actually happening.\n\n\"Wrestling historians will note this is actually the first time in history Hulk Hogan is putting someone over,\" quipped one X user, referring to how Hogan rarely lost his wrestling matches.\n\n\"Now is a good time to remind everyone that Hulk Hogan was fired from WWE because he got caught calling black people the n-word,\" wrote another.\n\n\"Hulk Hogan is on stage now, in case you're wondering how serious this country is,\" said one commenter.\n\nAnother added, \"We are close to Idiocracy becoming a full fledged prophecy.\"\n\n\"The final season of America is getting even more insane. Here's the very racist Hulk Hogan doing a very angry striptease,\" one viewer added.\n\nYou can check out more reaction to Hogan below and watch the full speech above.\n\nIf there's one person I don't wanna hear from, it's old Racist ass Hulk Hogan.He can choke on them Prayers & Vitamins.Sorry, but not Sorry. -- Bad News & Tattoos (@CarlieBravo) July 18, 2024\n\nIt's actually pretty genius of the RNC to have Hulk Hogan speak because he underscores the fact that American politics is, at root, WWE wrestling. pic.twitter.com/vavCcP8mOO -- Amanda Fortini (@amandafortini) July 19, 2024\n\nAs a kid in the late 70's/early 80's it's interesting that the iron sheik turned out to be the good guy and hulk hogan is actually the douchebag. pic.twitter.com/oEJfrAWAA7 -- Roger ZenAF (@RogerZenAF) July 18, 2024\n\nHulk Hogan is extremely appropriate here. racist language.\n\nThe latter caused him to be fired from World Wrestling Entertainment in 2015, where he had won major titles during his career. Vance 'the greatest tag team in my life' and warned they were 'getting ready to straighten this country out for all you real Americans.'\n\n'So all you criminals, all you low-lifes, all you scumbags, all you drug dealers and all you crooked politicians need to answer one question for me. 'And when I saw him stand up with that fist in the air and the blood on his face as a warrior, as a leader, I realized that's what America needs.'\n\n'I knew it all along,' the famed wrestler continued. I want to be Trump's running mate.\"\n\nFollowing the assassination attempt on Trump on July 13, Hogan shared a photo from the rally and expressed his political beliefs in a caption on Instagram.\n\n\"No President, past or present, should face such a horrific act,\" he wrote.\n\n\"Our thoughts and prayers are with President Trump, law enforcement and the Secret Service who bravely protect and uphold our shared values.\"\n\nIn an interview on Fox News ahead of tonight's event, Hogan told anchor Bret Baier that he felt compelled to speak after the assassination attempt.\n\n\"When they took a shot at my hero Donald Trump I realized I could not be silent anymore,\" he said.\n\n\"It rattled me to my core.\"\n\nWhen asked what his speech would entail, he responded, \"It's going to be like body-slamming a giant at Wrestlemania.\"\n\nHogan has expressed his political beliefs in the past and even teased ambitions in government.\n\nHe told Fox News' Brett Baier ahead of the RNC that he's thought about running for office \"several times.\"\n\nHogan has seemed to shift his political viewpoints, having previously endorsed Barack Obama for president.\n\nTrump has had a long history with WWE and was a close friend of Vince McMahon.\n\nMcMahon resigned from the WWE earlier this year due to allegations of sex trafficking and sexual assault.\n\nTrump first started appearing in WWE broadcasts in the 1980s but became a part of the show's plot in the late 2000s.\n\nHe and McMahon acted out a feud on WWE's Monday Night Raw that climaxed at WrestleMania 23 when Trump shaved A clip of the moment was shared to X, formerly Twitter, on Thursday, where it quickly went viral.\n\n\"Trump blowing a kiss to Hulk Hogan ... this cult is soooooo weird,\" user @WUTangKids captioned the snippet, which has received over 160,000 views.\n\nTrump's team has been emailed for comment.\n\nOthers thought Hogan had \"brought down the house\" during his appearance, after pointing to Trump in the audience, and describing the Republican candidate in November's general election as \"my hero\" and a \"Gladiator.\"\n\nThe 70-year-old also called Trump and his vice presidential pick JD Vance \"the greatest tag team of my life,\" claiming the Republican politician is going to \"bring America back together.\"\n\nWhile discussing the assassination attempt on Trump on Saturday, Hogan ripped off his shirt to reveal a vest top that read \"Trump-Vance 2024.\"\n\nTrump was speaking at a rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, last weekend when gunman Thomas Crooks open-fired with an AR15-style rifle. Trump was struck in his right ear before being rushed offstage by Secret Service agents. One person died and two were critically injured in the shooting.\n\nA spokesperson for Trump later said the 78-year-old was \"fine\" after being assessed at a hospital.\n\n\"When they took a shot at my hero, and they tried to kill the next president of the United States, enough was enough,\" Hogan shouted, causing the crowd to go wild.\n\n\"I said, 'Let Trumpamania run wild brother, let Vance 'the greatest tag team in my life' and warned they were 'getting ready to straighten this country out for all you real Americans.'\n\n'So all you criminals, all you low-lifes, all you scumbags, all you drug dealers and all you crooked politicians need to answer one question for me. 'You know the last time I was onstage Donald Trump was sitting ringside at Trump Plaza,' Hogan recalled.\n\nTrump Plaza was one of the ex-president's casino hotels in Atlantic City, New Jersey.\n\n'I was bleeding like a pig,' Hogan went on. 'And I won the world title right in front of Donald J. Trump!'\n\nPrior to taking the stage, Hogan told Fox News Bret Baier that Saturday's assassination attempt moved him into action, as he hadn't previously been a public supporter of the ex-president despite their decades-long relationship and Trump's other close ties with WWE.\n\n'Well, you know, Bret, I got tired of remaining silent,' Hogan said. 'You know, I sat back and watched the borders collapse. I watched the economy collapse. You know, I watched the price of gas, the price of food, everything just do an upside-down flip.'\n\n'And when they took a shot at my hero Donald Trump, I realized that I couldn't be silent anymore,' Hogan said.\n\nHogan posted a message to his Facebook page Saturday, which included the now iconic shot of Trump, blood spattered on his face, with his fist up.\n\n'It rattled me to my core when this happened,' Hogan said. 'And when I saw him stand up with that fist in the air and the blood on his face as a warrior, as a leader, I realized that's what America needs.'\n\n'I knew it all along,' the famed wrestler continued. JD Vance to be his running mate.\n\nHe said Thursday he was \"proud\" to support his hero as the next president.\n\nHe finished his speech with a question to politicians in the U.S.\n\n\"Whatcha gonna do when Donald Trump and all the Trump-a-maniacs run wild on you, brother?\"\n\nHogan, like Trump, is a WWE Hall of Famer. The 70-year-old's wrestling career over five decades as he made a name for himself in what was known as the World Wrestling Federation at the time and World Championship Wrestling. He also appeared in TNA Wrestling as well.\n\nAside from his pro wrestling appearances, Hogan was also in several films and TV shows, including, \"Rocky III,\" \"Thunder in Paradise,\" \"Mr. Nanny\" and was the subject of the reality TV show \"Hogan Knows Best.\"\n\nThe Georgia native' has had his share of controversies as well. He was wrapped up in a sex tape lawsuit against Gawker, which cost the company paid out millions. And was removed from the WWE Hall of Fame for a few years over racist remarks. Hogan apologized, was reinstated and received support from other African American pro wrestlers at the height of the controversy.\n\nCLICK HERE TO GET THE FOX NEWS APP\n\nSince his retirement from pro wrestling, Hogan has been seen sparingly on WWE TV. Trump is expected to accept his nomination tonight as the GOP presidential candidate facing President Joe Biden in November.\n\nTerry Gene Bollea, far better known by his ring name Hogan, helped propel the professional wrestling promotion and media organization World Wrestling Entertainment, or WWE, to fame. He won six WWE championships, starred in movies and television shows and cultivated a mass of fans he dubbed his \"Hulkamaniacs,\" according to his WWE bio.\n\nIn 2015, WWE cut ties with Hogan after audio was released of him repeatedly using a racial slur to describe a man his daughter was involved with at the time. Three years later, the company reinstated him into its Hall of Fame, saying he deserved a second chance after apologizing.\n\nIn mid-June, Hogan said in an interview with Fox News he'd be willing to enter the political arena.\n\n\"If you need a president or vice president, I'll volunteer and take this country over, and I'll rule with an iron fist,\" he told hosts of the show \"Fox and Friends.\"\n\nThat wasn't the first time he's raised the idea. "title": "Trump-a-maniac: Hulk Hogan to speak at RNC ahead of 45's acceptance speech", "body": "The Republican National Convention will close with a nomination-acceptance speech by former President Donald Trump, but not until after the crowd has been hyped up by pro wrestling icon Hulk Hogan.\n\nHogan and Trump go way back, to at least WrestleMania IV and V, which were both held at Trump Plaza in the late 80s.\n\nBack then it was Trump the ' Hulkamaniac ' watching from the front rows while the wrestlers took center stage.\n\nOn Thursday, according to NBC, all eyes will be on the only World Wrestling Entertainment Hall of Fame inductee-president as he accepts the Republican nomination for a third time running, while Hogan hangs out ringside.\n\n\"Two senior campaign officials confirmed to NBC News that Hulk Hogan will speak tonight at the RNC convention ahead of former President Trump formally accepting the GOP nomination for President of the United States,\" the network said via X, the social media app formerly known as Twitter.\n\nFormer Trump Administration Small Business Administrator Linda McMahon, also an ex-professional wrestler and a WWE executive, addressed the convention crowd in Milwaukee on Wednesday.\n\nA prime-time appearance by Hogan at the important political conference could be seen as part of his long-running come-back story arc.\n\nThe 70-year-old, whose real name is Terry Gene Bollea, was once removed from the WWE Hall of Fame and scrubbed from their website over blatantly racist comments he allegedly made in 2007 that were included in a sex tape which leaked in 2015. Three years later Hogan's place in the Hall of Fame was restored.\n\nAlso speaking on the convention's last day is Ultimate Fighting Championship CEO Dana White.\n\n\u00a92024 MediaNews Group, Inc. {"uri": "2024-07-427253067", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "14:16:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T14:16:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T13:16:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/lifestyles/entertainment/hulk-hogan-rips-off-his-shirt-at-republican-national-convention-viewers-react/article_369d2990-b8cb-53df-a924-a1bcd7a2e6a8.html", "title": "Hulk Hogan Rips Off His Shirt at Republican National Convention  --  Viewers React", "body": "As the world of politics and the theatrical world of professional wrestling continues to blur, it only made sense that Hulk Hogan would be asked to make a speech at the Republican National Convention.\n\nThe former pro-wrestler and WWE Hall of Famer, who just last month said he hadn't yet decided whom he would support in this year's election, spoke ahead of former president Donald Trump at Thursday's (July 18) Republican National Convention in Milwaukee, Wisconsin.\n\nDressed in a red bandanna, a navy blazer, and a black \"Real American\" vest, Hogan told the crowd, \"As an entertainer, I try to stay out of politics. But after everything that's happened to our country over the past four years and everything that happened last weekend, I can no longer stay silent.\"\n\nThen, in a fired-up wrestling-style promo, Hogan removed his suit jacket and said, \"But what happened last week, when they took a shot at my hero, and they tried to kill the next president of the United States, enough was enough!\"\n\nHe then ripped off his vest to reveal a red Trump-Vance tank top underneath. \"Let Trump-a-mania run wild, brother. Let Trump-a-mania rule again. Let Trump-a-mania make America great again,\" he continued as the crowd erupted in cheers.\n\nTrump was seen raising his fist in the air in reaction to Hogan's speech, and he even blew him a kiss. Of course, the Republican presidential candidate is no stranger to wrestling; he is also a member of the WWE Hall of Fame and famously appeared at WrestleMania 23, where he took a Stone Cold Stunner from Steve Austin.\n\nOnline reactions to Hogan's speech ranged from ridicule to shock that this was actually happening.\n\n\"Wrestling historians will note this is actually the first time in history Hulk Hogan is putting someone over,\" quipped one X user, referring to how Hogan rarely lost his wrestling matches.\n\n\"Now is a good time to remind everyone that Hulk Hogan was fired from WWE because he got caught calling black people the n-word,\" wrote another.\n\n\"Hulk Hogan is on stage now, in case you're wondering how serious this country is,\" said one commenter.\n\nAnother added, \"We are close to Idiocracy becoming a full fledged prophecy.\"\n\n\"The final season of America is getting even more insane. {"uri": "8232876652", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "05:20:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T05:20:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T05:19:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/world-news/watch-hulk-hogan-calls-trump-a-hero-rips-shirt-to-reveal-trump-vance-tank-top-at-rnc/articleshow/111852955.cms", "title": "Watch: Hulk Hogan calls Trump a 'hero,' rips shirt to reveal 'Trump-Vance' tank top at RNC", "body": "Hogan, an iconic figure from the 1980s whose real name is Terry Gene Bollea, spoke passionately on stage ahead of Trump's closing speech on the fourth day of the event. \"With our leader up there, my hero, that gladiator, we're gonna bring America back together,\" he declared.Famed US professional wrestling star Hulk Hogan endorsed Donald Trump for president on Thursday, making a dramatic entrance at the Republican National Convention (RNC) in Milwaukee. In his signature style, Hogan ripped off his shirt to reveal another underneath bearing the Republican candidate's name.\n\nHogan, an iconic figure from the 1980s whose real name is Terry Gene Bollea, spoke passionately on stage ahead of Trump's closing speech on the fourth day of the event. \"With our leader up there, my hero, that gladiator, we're gonna bring America back together,\" he declared.\n\nDrawing a comparison to his wrestling days, Hogan likened Trump and his vice-presidential running mate J.D. Vance to the dynamic duo act he once performed with \"Macho Man\" Randy Savage, known as The Mega Powers. Emulating his wrestling persona, the 70-year-old Hogan tore off his outer T-shirt to reveal a red one underneath, showcasing the Trump-Vance presidential ticket.\n\nAs he entered the packed auditorium filled with Republican delegates who had just nominated Trump as the party's presidential candidate, Hogan said he felt like he was in front of \"real Americans.\"\n\nHogan's endorsement comes despite a controversial past. Over a decade ago, he was involved in a scandal after an intimate video of him was leaked. Additionally, he faced backlash for his use of racist language, which led to his firing from World Wrestling Entertainment (WWE) in 2015, where he had won numerous major titles during his career. Hogan showed off his ripped and tanned physique as he ripped his shirt off to reveal and vest with Trump and his running mate JD Vance's names on it. {"uri": "8232313644", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "18:59:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T18:59:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T18:59:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://heavy.com/sports/pro-wrestling/hulk-hogan-trump-rnc/", "title": "Hulk Hogan Speech at RNC Sends 'Hulkamania' Running 'Wild': Report", "body": "Hulk Hogan is scheduled to speak at the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, on July 18, the RNC confirmed.\n\nHogan is slated to speak between 7:30 p.m. and 8 p.m., shortly before former President Donald Trump takes the podium, according to a schedule posted by the RNC. The wrestling legend is described by the RNC as a \"professional entertainer and wrestler.\"\n\n\"Hulkamania will be running wild at the Republican National Convention before Trump speaks,\" the publication Cageside Seats reported.\n\nHogan was recently undecided on Trump.\n\nIn a June 26 interview on NewsNation, Hogan had said he couldn't pick yet between Trump and President Joe Biden, saying the first debate would help him decide. That debate sparked a flurry of Democratic concern about Biden, Fox News reported.\n\n\"I'm for the guy who's going to straighten this country out, whoever that person is,\" Hogan said to NewsNation, adding that he was looking for a \"truth teller.\"\n\nHogan is one of three sports figures who will speak on the final evening of the RNC, the RNC schedule says. Dana White, CEO of Ultimate Fighting Championship, is scheduled to speak right before Trump, according to the RNC schedule.\n\nLinda McMahon, described as \"former Administrator of Small Business Administration,\" is speaking as well, the RNC schedule says. McMahon was previously \"the President and later CEO of World Wrestling Entertainment, Inc.,\" according to her bio on the American First Policy Institute website. She is the wife of WWE founder Vince McMahon, although they separated in 2022, In Touch Weekly reported.\n\nHogan posted about the assassination attempt against Trump on his Instagram page. \"Today's events in Butler, Pennsylvania are deeply disturbing,\" he wrote.\n\n\"No President, past or present, should face such a horrific act. Our thoughts and prayers are with President Trump, law enforcement, and the Secret Service who bravely protect and uphold our shared values,\" wrote Hogan.\n\nTrump was shot in the ear during the assassination attempt in Butler, Pennsylvania, he wrote on Truth Social. His speech on July 18 accepting the Republican nomination for president will be his first since the attempt on his life. President Joe Biden is the presumptive Democratic nominee for president.\n\nHogan previously revealed that he could begin a career in government.\n\n\"Hey, you never know,\" Hogan said in the NewsNation interview in June about working in the White House.\n\n\"Right now, I'd make a great vice president, brother, because I do have common sense. I do know right from wrong,\" he said in that interview.\n\nHe supported Democrat President Barack Obama and then Republican Mitt Romney for president, NewsNation reported.\n\nAsked who was his pick between Trump and Biden, Hogan revealed in June to NewsNation: \"At the end of the day, I'm just wanting somebody to straighten out the gas prices, the food prices, our nation's security. I want peace in the Middle East. I just want somebody with common sense, that knows right from wrong, brother. That's who I want to be president.\"\n\nAsked who he wanted between the two, though, he said to newsNation, \"I can't pick right now. The debate that's going to be the tell-all.\" He added that he would have to \"put myself\" in the mix. {"uri": "8232694058", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "02:09:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T02:09:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T02:07:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/hulk-hogan-know-wrestling-legend-015249216.html", "title": "Who is Hulk Hogan? What to know about wrestling legend who ripped off his shirt at RNC", "body": "Professional wrestler Hulk Hogan spoke Thursday at the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee.\n\nHogan, 70, gave a rousing speech ahead of Donald Trump during the final day of the convention. The former president is expected to formally accept the Republican nomination for November's presidential election tonight as well.\n\nThe RNC has been taking place in Milwaukee since Monday, and Hogan joined a long slate of celebrities and political leaders who praised Trump, calling for voters to elect him as the the next president.\n\nBorn Terry Gene Bollea in Augusta, Georgia, Hulk Hogan is one of the greatest -- certainly one of the most attention-getting -- professional wrestlers of all time.\n\n\"The key figure in WWE's rise from regional attraction to worldwide entertainment leader in the 1980s, The Hulkster's superhuman size and undeniable charisma set the standard for what a Superstar should be,\" WWE writes in Hogan's biography. \"A larger-than-life icon, he packed 93,173 WWE fans into the Pontiac Silverdome, won six WWE Championships, starred in movies, television shows and his own animated series and became an idol to a vast legion of fans he dubbed his Hulkamaniacs.\"\n\nAccording to Pro Wrestling Wiki, Hogan is a 12-time World Champion, including six WWF/WWE championships, six WCW World Heavyweight championships, and is a former WWE World Tag Team Champion with fellow wrestler Edge.\n\nAfter a 35-year career, Hogan officially retired from wrestling in 2012.\n\nHogan is a registered Republican and has shared some of his voting history (supporting Obama in 2008 and Romney in 2012) and even declared his potential aspirations for running for office.\n\nAccording to The Hill, he said if he ever ran, he would run as a Republican but at the moment, he doesn't have any plans to actually run for president.\n\n\"I've thought about it -- as of late, people calling my phone, driving me crazy about running for Senate. They want me to run for governor, they want me to run for mayor,\" the former professional wrestling star told TMZ's Harvey Levin\n\nAccording to the Ashbury Park Press, this won't be the first time Trump and the controversial pro wrestling star are teaming up.\n\nHogan competed at Wrestlemania IV and V, which were both held at Trump's Taj Mahal. Those events were held in 1988 and 1989. They're also both part of the WWE Hall of Fame.\n\nUSA TODAY will provide livestream coverage on YouTube each night of the RNC, Monday through Thursday.\n\nContributing: C. A. Let Trumpamania rule again. Let Trumpamania make America great again!\" as reported by Politico. The spotlight of the night fell on Hogan when he condemned the recent rifle attack on Trump at the Butler rally. \"I think about how Donald Trump and his family were compromised. When I look out there and I see Donald Trump, I think about how his business was compromised.\" Roaring louder on the mic Hogan said, \"But what happened last week when they took a shot at my hero, and they tried to kill the next president of the United States, enough was enough!\"\n\nTaking up the stage congratulating the ex-POTUS on his formal nomination by the Republican Party Hogan said, \"When I came here tonight, there was so much energy in this room, I felt maybe I was in Madison Square Garden getting ready to win another world title... but what I found out was I was in a room full of real Americans, brother. And at the end of the day, with our leader up there, my hero, that gladiator, we're gonna bring America back together, one real American at a time, brother,\" according to Entertainment Weekly. In a trademark move, Hogan ripped open his shirt, amid chants of \"Make America Geart Again!\".\n\nFamous wrestler & entertainer, Hulk Hogan electrified Day 4 of the Republican Convention. Hogan supported Trump for the next US President with a shirt-ripping speech. Addressing the crowd, Hogan passionately condemned the recent attack on Donald Trump. But after everything that's happened to our country over the past four years and everything that happened last weekend, I can no longer stay silent.\"\n\nThen, in a fired-up wrestling-style promo, Hogan removed his suit jacket and said, \"But what happened last week, when they took a shot at my hero, and they tried to kill the next president of the United States, enough was enough!\"\n\nHe then ripped off his vest to reveal a red Trump-Vance tank top underneath. \"Let Trump-a-mania run wild, brother. A large bandage has been taped to the side of his head after a bullet grazed him in an assassination attempt less than a week ago.\n\nTrump's speech Thursday evening will mark his first public address since the shooting Saturday that abruptly cut his speech short at a campaign rally in Pennsylvania. The former president's ear was bloodied by a bullet before Secret Service agents rushed him off stage. One attendee at the rally was killed, while two others were wounded. The shooter was killed by Secret Service countersnipers.\n\nOther figures from the wrestling and combat sports worlds are slated to speak at the convention Thursday, including Ultimate Fighting Championship CEO Dana White, and Linda McMahon, who co-founded WWE with her husband, Vince McMahon, and who served as Trump's small business administrator during his first term.\n\nHogan has himself previously toyed with a political run and even said earlier this year that he would consider entering the political ring if he's asked to do so.\n\n\"Hey, you never know,\" Hogan said in a NewsNation interview in June when asked if he could take up a role at the White House. \"Right now, I'd make a great vice president, brother, because I do have common sense. Hogan, showcasing his muscular physique, ripped off his shirt to reveal a vest with Trump and his running mate JD Vance's names. This was Hogan's first appearance at a political event, and he was clearly excited.\n\nStarting his speech with his signature WWE catchphrase, \"Well let me tell you something, brother,\" Hogan, whose real name is Terry Bollea, stated, \"I didn't come here as Hulk Hogan. I'm here tonight to show the world that Donald Trump is a real hero.\"\n\nHogan continued to tear off his shirt, declaring, \"Someone took a shot at my hero, and they tried to kill the next president of the United States.\"\n\nThe crowd erupted as Hogan shouted, \"Enough is enough,\" and further energized the audience with, \"Let Trumpmania run wild, brother. Let Trumpmania rule again. Let Trumpmania make America Great Again.\"\n\nTrump, visibly pleased, smiled and blew a kiss at Hogan during his performance. The crowd's reaction was so intense that Franklin Graham, president of the Billy Graham Evangelistic Association, joked about the challenge of following Hogan's act on stage.\n\nIn his first speech since the attempted assassination, Trump mentioned he immediately recognized the seriousness of the attack and felt reassured by his faith. He also observed a moment of silence for the victim of the rally shooting.\n\nAt the convention, Trump formally accepted the Republican nomination for president, promising an \"incredible victory\" in the upcoming November election. Check out the wild clip of his promo here...\n\nUnless you've been living under a rock, chances are you've heard about the recent assassination attempt on former U.S. President Donald Trump.\n\nNow wearing a bandage on his ear following the incident, Trump has been taking centre stage at the Republican National Convention this week and has had plenty of noteworthy supporters on hand. However, we'd be willing to bet you didn't count on WWE Hall of Famer Hulk Hogan being among them!\n\nHogan is a longtime supporter of Trump, but in a clip that's gone viral over the past 12 hours or so, he's seen hitting the Republican National Convention stage to his classic WWE theme song before delivering a rousing promo about the Republican nominee.\n\nThe impassioned Hogan told attendees, \"What happened last week...when they took a shot at my hero...They tried to kill the greatest president of the United States! Enough was enough!\"\n\nWith that, he tore off his shirt to reveal another - a Trump/Vance 2024 t-shirt - beneath it.\n\nHe'd also tell the crowd, \"Over my career, I've been in the ring with some of the biggest, some of the baddest dudes on the planet, and I've squared off against warriors, ooh yeah, savages.\"\n\n\"And I've even, like I said, body-slammed giants in the middle of the ring. And I know tough guys, but let me tell you something, brother, Donald Trump is the toughest of them all,\" Hogan continued. \"All you criminals, all you lowlifes, all you scumbags... Whatcha gonna do when Donald Trump and all the Trumpamaniacs run wild on you, brother?\"\n\nAfter explaining why he's chosen to openly campaign for someone he claims to have been friends with for 35 years (it's always hard to say with Hogan; he's become infamous for telling tall tales and once said he worked 400 days in a single year), the wrestler bellowed, \"Let Trump-O-Mania rule again, let Trump-O-Mania make America great again!\n\nIf you're wondering why Hogan was there to introduce Trump, it's likely because the Presidential candidate is a longtime pro wrestling fan. He's been involved in a few high-profile WWE storylines, primarily with his longtime friend and former WWE Chairman Vince McMahon.\n\nHogan remains a divisive figure among wrestling fans; a 2015 leaked video saw him making racist comments about his daughter's then-boyfriend, prompting WWE to cut ties with him. Hulk Hogan to speak at RNC on behalf of Donald Trump", "body": "According to published reports, Hulk Hogan will speak tonight (July 18) at the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee. Former President Donald Trump is expected to formally accept the Republican nomination for November's presidential election tonight as well.\n\nThis isn't the first time Trump and the controversial pro wrestling star were a tag team.\n\nHogan competed at Wrestlemania IV and V, which were both held at Trump's Taj Mahal. Those events were held in 1988 and 1989.\n\nThey're also both part of the WWE Hall of Fame.\n\nHogan has plenty of pros and a lot of cons, which makes him an odd choice as a speaker.\n\nOne of the most popular athletes of all time, Hogan's star faded in recent years after he was caught using a racial slur on video -- the same video that was released of him having consensual sex with his friend's wife.\n\nGawker released the video. Hogan won $31 million in a lawsuit with the media company, but it cost him some of his credibility.\n\nWorld Wrestling Entertainment distanced itself from Hogan after the incident, which happened a little over a decade ago. But since then he has worked to rebuild his reputation, and is now back with WWE during big events.\n\nHulk Hogan Sayings\n\nThis isn't the first time a wrestle spoke at the RNC.\n\nIn 2000, Dwayne \"The Rock\" Johnson spoke at the Republican National Convention at the First Union Center in Philly. But Hogan has a unique speaking style. So let's take a look at things the \"Immoral\" one might say.\n\nWhatcha Gonna Do, USA?\n\nThis is probably his most famous saying. I guess this would be a good way to survey who people are voting for. Chances are most of the RNC are siding with Trump, so this is a safe one.\n\nBrother\n\nHogan calls everyone brother, brother! Sometimes he throws Jack in there, but most people are his brother. He's never used sister, but that could be problematic tonight because there will be women there. Oh brother!\n\nTrain, say your prayers and vote for Donald!\n\nThe third part of that saying, of course is \"take your vitamins,\" but it's 2024, people know what they have to take to stay healthy. Throwing Donald in there would keep the bulk of the same message while including the reason he's there.\"\n\nBiden doesn't work for me, brother!\n\nDon't tell anyone but wrestling is fixed. Rumor has it whenever Hogan, who was one of the most popular wrestlers of all time and a master politician behind the curtain, would say \"this doesn't work for me, brother\" when his character was to look bad and, gasp, lose a predetermined match.\n\nTouting Donald's 24-inch pythons\n\nHogan's pythons are his biceps. He says they measure 24 inches around. Trump's don't, but neither did Hogan's. Wrestling is a lot like politics.\n\nTrumpamania running wild\n\nHogans fans were Hulkamaniacs. So it makes sense that if you vote for Trump, you'd be a Trumpamaniac.\n\nDana White\n\nHogan isn't the only combat sport personality set to appear tonight. Dana White, the UFC CEO, is slated to introduce Trump tonight. A large bandage has been taped to the side of his head after a bullet grazed him in an assassination attempt less than a week ago.\n\nTrump's speech Thursday evening will mark his first public address since the shooting Saturday that abruptly cut his speech short at a campaign rally in Pennsylvania. The former president's ear was bloodied by a bullet before Secret Service agents rushed him off stage. One attendee at the rally was killed while two others were wounded.\n\nOther figures from the wrestling world are slated to speak at the RNC on Thursday, including Ultimate Fighting Championship (UFC) CEO Dana White and Linda McMahon, who co-founded WWE with her husband, Vince McMahon and who served as Trump's Small Business Administrator during his first term.\n\nHogan has himself previously toyed with a political run, and even said earlier this year that he would consider entering the political ring if he's asked to do so.\n\n\"Hey, you never know,\" Hogan said in a NewsNation interview in June when asked if he could take up a role at the White House. \"Right now, I'd make a great vice president, brother, because I do have common sense. He performed his iconic T-shirt rip, exciting the crowd with chants of 'USA!' and declared Trump his hero, promising to 'bring America back together.'\n\nRetired professional wrestler Hulk Hogan brought back his World Wrestling Entertainment (WWE) persona on stage Friday at the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee to support former President Donald Trump. Before Trump accepted the Republican nomination, the WWE Hall of Famer, dressed in a navy blue suit, sunglasses, and a red bandana, took to the stage to endorse him.\n\nHogan, sporting his trademark blond handlebar mustache, delivered a highly energetic speech. He removed his jacket to reveal a sleeveless black shirt emblazoned with 'real American.' He then performed his iconic T-shirt rip.\n\nBeneath the black shirt, he showcased a Trump/Vance Red Hulk Hogan T-shirt, declaring he'd seen 'the greatest tag team of my life.' Pointing to Trump in the audience, Hogan exclaimed, 'With our leader up there, my hero, that gladiator, we are gonna bring America back together. One real American at a time, brother!'\n\nThe crowd roared 'USA, USA' at Hogan's antics. Hogan, whose real name is Terry G. Bollea, called Trump his 'hero' and added, 'But what happened last week when they took a shot at my hero and tried to kill the president of the United States, enough was enough,' Hogan said.\n\n'Let Trump-O-Mania rule again; let Trump-O-Mania make America great again,' he roared to cheers from the crowd. Trump attended the convention after a shooter attempted to assassinate him at a Milwaukee rally last week.\n\nAfter ducking to the ground as a bullet grazed his ear, Trump rose and raised his fist, shouting 'fight! fight! fight!' before U.S. Secret Service personnel formed a protective ring around him and escorted him away safely. Days later, on July 18, Hogan brought Hulkamania to the Republican National Conference by speaking on how the shooting at the Trump rally had left him enraged. \"When they took a shot at my hero. And they tried to kill the next president of the United States. Enough was enough,\" Hogan said during his speech. \"And I said, 'Let Trumpamania run wild, brother,'\" he added while taking off his blazer and tearing off his t-shirt to reveal a Trump-Pence shirt underneath.\n\nThe WWE theatrics left people both buzzing, and befuddled. \"It really feels like we are living in a giant movie right now,\" one X, formerly Twitter, user wrote. As he stumped for Trump, Hogan tore the shirt off his chest, revealing a MAGA message underneath.\n\nThe legendary former WWE star, known for his larger-than-life persona, received thunderous cheers at the Republican National Convention as he prepared the stage for Trump. In his address, Hogan urged, \"I want All the Hulkmaniancs to live the American dream too.\"\n\nHogan rallied against the Biden administration, saying: \"We never had it better than the Trump years, we had safety, we had peace... And then we lost it... Crime is out of control,\" He then went on to warn, \"So all you criminals, all you lowlives, all you scumbags... whatcha gonna do when Donald Trump is president again.\"\n\nREAD MORE: Donald Trump shooter 'scoped out' member of Royal Family in assassination plot\n\nReaching a frenzy in his speech, Hogan began to undress, while shouting: \"When they took a shot at my hero and they tried to kill the next President of the United States, enough was enough. I said 'Let Trumpmania run wild brother, let Trumpmania rule again, let Trumpmania make America great again',\" before ripping his shirt in two.\n\nBehind the scenes, two top campaign aides disclosed to NBC that the 70 year old wrestling veteran would make an appearance at the RNC's last day to make remarks before Trump's eagerly awaited acceptance speech. The evening marked Trump's first public speaking event since an assassination attempt was made against him at a Butler, Pennsylvania rally, reports the Mirror US.\n\nAnd while Trump escaped with only minor injuries, the dreadful assault tragically claimed the life of 50 year old Corey Comperatore and critically injured two others. In response to this tragedy, Hogan aired his condemnation of the brutal act on social media as he expressed support for Trump.\n\nThat Saturday night, Hogan quickly took to Instagram to post a trending picture of an embattled Trump, head held high and fist raised, whilst blood streamed down from a grazed ear inflicted by a bullet on stage.\n\nUnderneath the harrowing image, Hogan delivered a message to his 2.5 million followers that stated: \"Today's events in Butler, Pennsylvania are deeply disturbing. No President, past or present, should face such a horrific act.\"\n\nThe wrestler-turned-actor who hails from Florida continued: \"Our thoughts and prayers are with President Trump, law enforcement and the Secret Service who bravely protect and uphold our shared values.\"\n\nHogan was expected too to the stage at the Republican National Convention on Thursday, July 18, between 7.30pm and 8pm He told the hosts of Fox & Friends last month that he was interested in taking a turn in politics after spending over three decades in wrestling and entrepreneurship. \"We need somebody in there that's got some common sense, you know what I'm saying?\" Hogan said. \"So if you need a president or a vice president, I'll volunteer and take this country over, and I'll rule with an iron fist.\"\n\nHogan also considered running for Senate in Florida in 2018, and has openly criticized pseudo-liberal companies and positions. He appeared on Fox & Friends last month to push his new beer venture, Real American Beer, which the former wrestler said he created after seeing Bud Light's fallout with conservatives following an ad campaign released with transgender influencer Dylan Mulvaney. The can depicts a wrestler waving an American flag, and Hogan said he hopes to \"bring America back together, one beer at a time.\"\n\nIn 2015, he was fired from WWE for using the N-word to describe his daughter's then-boyfriend years earlier. He released a brief statement at the time apologizing for using \"language that is offensive and inconsistent with my beliefs.\"\n\nHogan speaking at the RNC emphasizes the degree to which Trump has turned Republican politics into something akin to professional wrestling, injecting it with name-calling, ostentatious theatrics, and a glitzy cast of characters. Vance to himself and former tag-team partner Macho Man Randy Savage, collectively known as The Mega Powers in the 1980s.\n\nThe 70-year-old sparked delight among those in attendance when he ripped off his shirt in trademark fashion, revealing a red one underneath displaying his support for Trump and Vance.\n\nHe told the room packed with Republican delegates that he felt he was in the presence of 'real Americans'.\n\nHogan became embroiled in a race row in 2015 after video footage showed him using language of a racist nature.\n\nDespite his grovelling apologies, Hogan's WWE contract was subsequently terminated. {"uri": "8234092351", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "20:09:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T20:09:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T20:08:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.latimes.com/entertainment-arts/tv/story/2024-07-19/hulk-hogan-shirt-trump-rnc-republican-convention", "title": "Hulk Hogan rips off his shirt during fiery RNC speech: 'Let Trumpamania run wild'", "body": "Hulk Hogan's wrestling days may be behind him, but the all-American persona he brought to the ring is going strong.\n\nThe six-time World Wrestling Entertainment champion took the stage Thursday at the Republican National Convention to endorse former President Trump, whom he called a friend of more than 35 years. During his speech, Hogan also pronounced the Republican presidential nominee -- and WWE Hall of Famer -- a \"hero\" and \"gladiator.\"\n\n\"When I came here tonight, there was so much energy in this room I felt maybe I was in Madison Square Garden getting ready to win another world title,\" said Hogan, born Terry Bollea, in kicking off his speech. \"But what I found out was I was in a room of real Americans, brother.\" (Thus arrived the first of many references to Hogan's longtime entrance theme, \"Real American.\")\n\nThe WWE in 2015 terminated its contract with Hogan after it was reported that he had been videotaped using a racial slur. That year, the wrestling star told TMZ he had no \"hard feelings\" toward the organization -- and expressed a desire to be Trump's running mate. Still, Hogan on Thursday gave his blessing to vice presidential nominee J.D. Vance, calling the Republican ticket \"the greatest tag team\" he'd ever seen.\n\nThen, when he broached Saturday's attempted assassination of Trump, Hogan went full-throttle on the theatrics.\n\nTearing his shirt to reveal a MAGA-red Trump-Vance muscle tank underneath, he cried, \"Let Trumpamania run wild, brother. Let Trumpamania rule again. Let Trumpamania make America great again.\" Trump blew him a kiss.\n\n\"As an entertainer, I try to stay out of politics, but after everything that's happened to our country over the past four years, and everything that happened last weekend, I can no longer stay silent,\" Hogan said. \"I'm here tonight because I want the world to know that Donald Trump is a real American hero, and I'm proud to support my hero as the next president of this United States.\"\n\nHogan went on to laud Trump for his commitment to running for office despite his dual impeachments and criminal and civil cases: \"I know tough guys, but let me tell you something, brother. Donald Trump is the toughest of them all.\"\n\nHe capped off his endorsement with a play on his catchphrase, \"Whatcha gonna do when Hulkamania runs wild on you?\"\n\n\"Whatcha gonna do when Donald Trump and all the Trumpamaniacs run wild on you, brother?\" he roared, to the crowd's delight.\n\nBut Hogan was only the first of two sports-entertainment figureheads to take the RNC stage Thursday night.\n\nLater in the evening, at Trump's personal request, Dana White, president and chief executive of the Ultimate Fighting Championship, introduced the presidential nominee, calling him a \"fighter\" and \"real American badass.\"\n\n\"I'm in the tough-guy business, and this man is the toughest, most resilient human being that I've ever met in my life,\" White said.\n\nTrump then addressed the RNC's 50,000 attendees -- many of whom had donned ear bandages to match his own.\n\n\"Together, we will save this country, we will restore the republic, and we will usher in the rich and {"uri": "2024-07-427048829", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "11:09:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T11:09:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T10:01:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.femalefirst.co.uk/celebrity/hulk-hogan-rips-shirt-demands-return-trump-mania-1403189.html", "title": "Hulk Hogan rips shirt off and demands return of 'Trump-o-mania'", "body": "Hulk Hogan ripped his shirt off during a speech at the Republican National Convention as he backed Donald Trump to return to the White House.\n\nHulk Hogan ripped his shirt off on stage at the Republican National Convention\n\nThe veteran wrestler - who has known the former US President for more than 35 years - took to the stage to speak at the event in Milwaukee on Thursday (18.07.24) after Trump was confirmed as the party's official nominee for the US election in November and he drove the crowd wild by taking off his suit jacket and ripping off a tank top to reveal a red Trump/Vance shirt underneath.\n\nAfter coming on stage to the tune of his wrestling theme 'Real American', he pumped the audience up with his catchphrase, saying: \"Well, let me tell you something brother!\" before referencing the assassination attempt on Trump in Pennsylvania last Saturday (13.07.24) when a gun man opened fire on the politician leaving Trump with a wounded ear and killing a crowd-member.\n\nHogan said: \"What happened last week ...when they took a shot at my hero ....They tried to kill the greatest president of the United States. Enough was enough!!\"\n\nHe also recalled winning a wrestling world title in front of keen fan Trump and went on to pledge his support to his old friend, adding: \"Over my career, I've been in the ring with some of the biggest, some of the baddest dudes on the planet, and I've squared off against warriors, ooh yeah, savages.\n\n\"And I've even, like I said, body-slammed giants in the middle of the ring. And I know tough guys, but let me tell you something, brother, Donald Trump is the toughest of them all.\n\n\"All you criminals, all you lowlifes, all you scumbags ... Whatcha gonna do when Donald Trump and all the Trumpamaniacs run wild on you, brother?\"\n\nHogan added: \"As as an entertainer, I tried to stay out of politics, but after everything that's happened to our country over the past four years and everything that happened last weekend [the assassination attempt], I can no longer be silent.\n\n\"I'm here tonight because I want the world to know that Donald Trump is a real American hero, and I'm proud to support my hero as the next president of this United States.\n\n\"I've known that man for over 35 years, and he's always been the biggest patriot, and he still is. He's always told you exactly what he thought, and he still does brother.\n\n\"Let Trump-O-Mania rule again, let Trump-O-Mania make America great again!\"\n\nTrump - who is a longtime wrestling fan and has long been involved with the WWE - was seen blowing Hogan a kiss as he finished his speech and later gave him a shout-out as he officially accepted the Republican nomination.\n\nHe said of Hogan: \"I know about entertainment, but when he used to lift a 350 pound man over his shoulders and then bench press him two rows into the audience, I said, that maybe entertainment, but he is one strong son-of-a-gun.\"\n\nTrump previously hosted WWE's flagship event WrestleMania IV and WrestleMania V at his Trump Plaza in Atlantic City, New Jersey and was a regular ringside.\n\nHe also took part in 2007's WrestleMania 23 - which was dubbed 'Battle of the Billionaires' - as Trump chose a champion fighter to take on a wrestler chosen by WWE Chairman Vince McMahon with the loser being forced to shave his head.\n\nTrump won and got to keep his famous head of hair and was later seen shaving McMahon's head. In the years that followed, Trump made numerous appearances on WWE programming.\n\n\"I've squared off against warriors, ooh yeah savages, and I've even like I said bodyslammed giants in the middle of the ring,\" Hogan said in reference to wrestlers The Ultimate Warrior, Randy \"Macho Man\" Savage, and Andre the Giant. And I know tough guys, but let me tell you something, brother, Donald Trump is the toughest of them all.\"\n\nHogan also touched on Trump's brush with death during last Saturday's rally in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\n\"What happened last week, when they took a shot at my hero and they tried to kill the next president of the United States, enough was enough! USA!\"\n\nHogan told the crowd the country \"never had it better\" than during the Trump years.\n\n\"But then we lost it all in the blink of an eye. Crime is out of control, the border is out of control, the price of food and gas is out of control, and the only person who can clean this up is Donald Trump,\" Hogan added.\n\n\"He's going to win in November, and we're all going to be champions again,\" Hogan told the crowd.\n\n\"No matter the odds, he always finds a way to win. One man that joined in on the praise was one of the greatest professional wrestlers of all time, Hulk Hogan.\n\n'Hulkamania' is a two-time WWE Hall-of-Fame inductee for the incredible work he put in over the years. Though retired, the 70-year-old remains a global star, and he just used his electrifying stature to deliver a fiery speech for former President Trump.\n\nSince getting shot and demanding Americans fight, Donald Trump has been the center of attention, and rightly so. As Trump battles to be reinstated into the White House, supporters are beginning to speak up and Hulk Hogan is just the latest.\n\n\"Well, let me tell you something, brother...\" a fired up Hogan said during his speech for Trump. \"At the end of the day, with our leader up there, my hero, that gladiator, we're going to bring America back together. One real American at a time.\"\n\n\"I've seen some great tag teams in my time. Hulk Hogan and 'The Macho Man' Randy Savage. Trump becomes the president of the United States, all the real Americans are going to be nicknamed 'Trumpites'.\"\n\n\"So, with the power of Donald J. Trump, and all the 'Trumpites' running wild, America is going to get back on track. And like Donald J. Trump said, America is going to be great again.\"\n\nHogan then ramped up his speech, cutting a memorable promo and tearing his top apart, reminiscent of the old days.\n\n\"I think about how Donald Trump, his family was compromised. But after everything that's happened to our country over the past four years, and everything that happened last weekend, I can no longer stay silent.\"\n\n\"I'm here tonight because I want the world to know that Donald Trump is a real American hero. {"uri": "8232689364", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "02:01:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T02:01:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T02:01:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://time.com/7000336/hulk-hogan-donald-trump-rnc/", "title": "Hulk Hogan Rips Off Shirt, Calls Trump His 'Hero' at RNC", "body": "Hulk Hogan, the iconic entertainer who electrified wrestling arenas in the 1980s and '90s, stepped into a new arena Thursday night: the political stage at the Republican National Convention.\n\nHogan spoke at the RNC shortly before Donald Trump was set to accept the party's nomination and delivered one of the most energetic speeches of the convention, calling Trump his \"hero\" and a \"gladiator\" before tearing off his shirt. Much like his wrestling matches of the past, his speech drew an enthusiastic response from the convention crowd.\n\nHogan's speech came less than a week after a shooter tried to assassinate Trump at a rally in Pennsylvania. \"What happened last week when they took a shot at my hero and they tried to kill the next President of the United States?\" Hogan, whose real name is Terry Bollea, said. \"Enough was enough. Run wild brother. Let Trump-a-mania rule again.\"\n\nRead More: America's Political Violence Crisis\n\nHogan then ripped off his shirt, echoing his famous wrestling entrance, revealing a Trump-Vance shirt underneath. He said that the assassination attempt on Trump was the moment he decided he wanted to make his voice heard: \"I tried to stay out of politics, but after everything that's happened to our country over the past four years and everything that happened last weekend, I can no longer stay silent,\" he said.\n\n\"Over my career, I've been in the ring with some of the biggest, some of the baddest dudes on the planet,\" Hogan continued. \"Donald Trump is the toughest of them all. They've thrown everything at Donald Trump, all the investigations, the impeachments, the court cases, and he's still standing and kicking their butts.\"\n\nHogan's presence at the RNC added a dose of spectacle and nostalgia to an event already steeped in theatrics. Hogan joined a speaker lineup that also included Linda McMahon, the matriarch of the wrestling empire, and UFC President Dana White.\n\nRead More: Why Trump Chose J.D. Vance\n\nTrump has long been a fan of professional wrestling. He was inducted into the WWE Hall of Fame in 2013, and said in his acceptance speech: \"I consider this to be my greatest honor of all.\" He's participated in several combat sporting events over the years, including \"Battle of the Billionaires\" at WWE's WrestleMania in 2007 when Trump took down Vince McMahon, co-founder of WWE.
