{"uri": "8232146886", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "16:41:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T16:41:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T16:40:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://www.thehollywoodgossip.com/2024/07/hulk-hogan-divorce-wife-sex-tape/", "title": "Hulk Hogan Divorced: His Marriage History With Sky Daily, Explained", "body": "Hulk Hogan is a divorced man, twice over. Is his third marriage heading in the same direction?\n\nIt was announced that the controversial WWE legend Hulk Hogan would speak at the RNC before Trump accepted the GOP nomination.\n\nIt's been awhile since Hogan has been on the world stage like that, as disgraces in his personal life have kept him squarely out of the limelight.\n\nAmong them include a sextape, getting fired from the WWE for using the N-Word, and two failed marriages.\n\nOf the latter, the details of his divorces are both messy and sad.\n\nIn the 1980's, there was no bigger name in wrestling than Hulk. In fact, some will argue that without Hogan, the WWE wouldn't be what it is today.\n\nBecause of that, when Hulk Hogan married Linda Claridge in 1983, the wedding was reportedly attended by everyone from Vince McMahon to Andre The Giant .\n\nTo the world, it appeared like the pair had the perfect marriage. They went on to welcome two children together: daughter Brooke and son Nick.\n\nThen came Hogan Knows Best, one of the first family reality shows of its kind. For 4 seasons, legions of fans tuned in to VH1 (is that still a channel?!) to watch Hulk and Linda wrangle their children and keep their marriage together.\n\nIn the end, the show was canceled - as was their marriage.\n\nIn November 2007, People Magazine reported that Linda had filed for a divorce. She apparently did so without telling Hulk Hogan, which will be ironic as this saga continues.\n\nA year later, Linda's publicist Gary Smith told E! News that Linda filed for divorce after she found out that Hulk had an affair with one of his daughter Brooke's close friends, Christine Plante.\n\n\"Almost every statement that comes out of Hulk's mouth is a diversionary tactic to deflect attention away from the real reason Linda filed for divorce, two words: HULK'S CHEATING!\" her publicist insisted.\n\nHulk has vehemently denied these claims, both in public through his own reps, and in his own words. In his autobiography, My Life Outside The Ring, Hulk acknowledged that Linda had repeatedly suspected him of having numerous infidelities, nothing romantic ever happened with any of the women he was \"friends\" with.\n\nThat became a hard pill to swallow when Brooke's friend Christine confirmed the affair herself.\n\n\"My relationship with [Hulk] began at a time when [Hulk] and Linda [Hogan] privately knew their marriage was ending,\" she told the National Enquirer.\n\n\"She had left him already, although no official papers had been filed. [Hulk] is a good man, good father, and good friend, and he and I grew close at a time when he was going through a very difficult period. It seemed right then, but I know it was wrong.\"\n\nThree years after Linda called it quits with Hulk, he married his second wife, Jennifer McDaniel, in 2010.\n\nAfter two years of dating, the pair pledged their love during a ceremony in Clearwater, Florida.\n\nThey stayed together for 11 years, and were seemingly very happy together.\n\nIn 2022, he posted a photo of himself and another woman (enter Sky Daily) on social media, and called her his \"girl\". Fans immediately flooded his accounts, confused over how he could have a new girlfriend when he was supposed to be married to Jennifer.\n\nThe answer? He \"forgot\" to mention he was divorced.\n\n\"Yo Maniacs just for the record, the Facebook and Instagram posts are of me and my girlfriend Sky, I am officially divorced,\" he wrote on then Twitter. \"Sorry I thought everyone already knew, love my Maniacs4Life\"\n\nIt was then that court documents were obtained by TMZ Sports that revealed they filed for divorce in October 2021.\n\nNo real reason ever came to light on why they split.\n\nWith the news of his second marriage being finished finally out of the way, Hulk pushed on with getting serious with his new girl, Sky Daily.\n\nTwo years after his last divorce, he married Sky in October 2023. Sky is reportedly a yoga instructor, and has three children from a previous marriage.\n\nSpeaking of kids, Brooke Hogan made it crystal clear that she had no interest in her father's new marriage and thus, did not attend his wedding.\n\n\"As many of you know, I value my privacy but unfortunately, a lot of media outlets are making assumptions as to why I did not attend my father's third wedding. Instead of leaving it to speculation, I decided it's better to shut it all down here,\" she posted. \"For my own journey to healing and happiness, I have chosen to create some distance between myself and my family, and am focusing on people and things that heal my heart and align with my own personal beliefs, goals, and values.\"\n\nAs for any rumblings of a divorce between Sky and Hulk, if there are problems in paradise, they are doing a great job of hiding. Just a week before his appearance at the RNC, Hulk treated his wife to a birthday surprise. The pair saw Jelly Roll in concert, who then serenaded her from the stage.\n\nHulk called Sky \"amazing\" and looked very in love in the video.\n\nSo, maybe the third time will be the charm for Hulk "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9744072", "eventUri": "eng-9744072", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.01960784313725483, "wgt": 152, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8233946254", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "17:49:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T17:49:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T17:48:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.telegraph.co.uk/tv/0/trump-hulk-hogan-presidential-run/", "title": "Hulk Hogan for President? Why his 1998 publicity stunt backfired", "body": "Former wrestler Hulk Hogan's latest publicity stunt is reminiscent of his mortifying bid to run for the 2000 Presidential campaign\n\nWalrus-moustached wrestling icon Hulk Hogan took the idea of a rip-roaring good time to the limit at the national convention of Donald Trump's Republican party this week. Standing at the podium on Thursday, he roared, then ripped open his shirt to reveal a second shirt bearing Trump's name. \"Let Trumpmania run wild, brother,\" said Hogan, hype-man to the former President ahead of Trump's address that evening. \"Let Trumpmania rule again! Let Trumpmania make America great again!\"\n\nHogan's heroics in Wisconsin have have generated international headlines but for long-time followers of this mainstay of Nineties wrestling, the display may have carried a hint of d\u00e9j\u00e0 vu. Hogan, after all, attempted much the same stunt 26 years ago at Nassau County Memorial Coliseum on Long Island. On November 9, 1998, flanked by \"secret service\" agents in dark suits and wearing his full wrestling kit, \"Hollywood\" Hogan stomped into the ring and, amid a riot of red, white and blue confetti, addressed the sold-out audience at the World Champion Wrestling \"Nitro\" event.\n\n\"If I can get America behind me... we shall turn the page, we shall give America a brand new start,\" said Hogan, striking the same beats of bull-headed triumphalism he would summon when introducing Trump. \"All my people that love America shall take us into the new millennium on a brand new start. I am here not only to serve but to protect my country.\"\n\nFans bawled their approval - but did they know what they were cheering? His ambitions would soon be spelt out. Hogan, the biggest force in wrestling, was announcing his run for the 2000 Presidential election campaign. Mr Hollywood was going to Washington.\n\nThree weeks later, Hogan - real name Terry Gene Bollea - clarified his plans during an appearance on a Thanksgiving night edition of Jay Leno's Tonight Show. He confirmed he was retiring from wrestling and putting on hold the movie career that had earned him the \"Hollywood\" nickname and had seen him star in blockbusters such as Three Ninjas, Mr Nanny and Suburban Commando.\n\n\"I had to come to the crossroads here,\" he told Leno. \"I've accomplished everything I wanted to do in wrestling. My family is secure. I've had a great career. I wanted to come on your show tonight and officially announce my retirement.\"\n\nLeno - who presumably had missed the announcement at Nassau County Coliseum - looked shocked. \"All good things must come to an end. I had a great career,\" continued Hogan. \"The fans have been great. I love you guys and thanks for sticking with me. And this really helps me segue into being the next President of the United States.\"\n\nHogan didn't have many specific policies to share with viewers - though he received a cheer when he announced one of the first things he would do if elected would be to institute a federal flat tax. That got a huge yell. The people were on his side.\n\nThe idea of a human bendy toy such as Hulk Hogan seeking the Presidency seems ludicrous in 2024. In 1998, it was genuinely plausible. One of Hogan's rivals, Jesse \"The Body\" Ventura, had already started what would become a successful run for Governor of Minnesota. Five years later, another Hollywood action star, Arnold Schwarzenegger, would use Leno's talk show to announce he was running for governor of California. Hulk Hogan fancying a tilt at the White House might have been a surprise, but it wasn't a joke.\n\nOr at least that is what Leno and his audience thought. However, it would quickly become apparent that Hogan's designs were not on the Oval Office but on boosting his profile in wrestling. He didn't make any further TV appearances to plug his candidacy, and he certainly didn't hold any campaign rallies. It was all just a publicity stunt to hype the next WCW event in January 1999.\n\nThe WCW needed the exposure. Established in 1988 by CNN's Ted Turner as a rival to the all-powerful WWF (later the WWE), it had enjoyed a brief period of popularity - but by the late 1990s, its profile was on the slide, despite the involvement of Hogan. The WCW needed the ineffable Hulk to put it in the spotlight once again.\n\nIt helped that Hogan talked a good game. Criticised by Ventura for riding on his coattails, he would later dismiss his competitor as \"a very small minnow in a big lake\".\n\n\"We all know the difference between John Wayne and an extra who gets a little part,\" he told radio interviewer Todd Alan Clem (aka Bubba The Love Sponge). \"We all know the difference between Jesse The Body Ventura and Hollywood Hulk Hogan.\"\n\nHe also claimed to have received support from Willie Nelson and Ted Turner. \"We want a real America,\" he said. \"Not one of the plastic politicians.\"\n\nHogan's heart may never have been in the Presidential race, but he nonetheless felt he had a chance. His campaign manager, WCW President Eric Bischoff, later pointed to a poll in Atlanta which he said showed that, had he gone up against Bill Clinton or Al Gore, Hogan would have won 61 per cent of the vote.\n\nStill, there was widespread scepticism within wrestling. An early 1999 edition of The Wrestler magazine openly queried how serious he was, with the headline, \"Hogan's Retirement: White House or White Lie?\"\n\nBy the time The Wrestler hit the shelves, that question had already been answered. On January 4 1999, Hogan made a surprise appearance at the WCW Monday Nitro event, where he tangled with WCW champion Kevin Nash, felling the younger wrestler with a single prod of his finger - what become known as \"the finger poke of doom\".\n\nThe square-off was immediately notorious - not because it undermined Hogan's claim to have retired but because of the ludicrous sight of a finger-prod felling the six-foot-10 inch tall Nash. So absurd was the stunt not even American wrestling fans could swallow it - the New York Post said the incident was \"widely considered the beginning of the end for WCW\", which was acquired by the WWE in 2001.\n\nHogan went back to his day job but never formally renounced his presidential campaign. In late 1999, appearing on Larry King Live, he suggested he might still run. \" It's something that's not out of the question because with everybody having a different agenda and everybody owing everybody something in the political arena, it would be nice to have somebody that could put America first,\" he said. \"The way I look at it, if Jesse Ventura could become governor of Minnesota, I mean, I basically beat Jesse at everything he's done anyway in his life, so I might as well run for the President.\"\n\nThis was just more hot air - though it fell far short of the smoke he blew at Donald Trump's RNC appearance this week. Hogan has since had his ups and downs: in 2015 he issued a public apology after he was caught using the \"n\" word in a leaked sex tape. But he was visibly having the time of his life as Trump's cheerleader. After a lifetime of pretend-tossing people around the ring, the thrill he felt at joining Trump in a real-life political cage fight was there for the whole world to see.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8232678030", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "01:46:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T01:46:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T01:45:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.kpbs.org/news/politics/2024/07/18/hulk-hogan-and-other-sports-icons-will-speak-ahead-of-trump-at-rnc-convention", "title": "Hulk Hogan and other sports icons will speak ahead of Trump at RNC convention", "body": "For more updates from the 2024 Republican National Convention in Milwaukee, head to the NPR Network's live updates page. Plus: You can watch live video coverage from NPR of tonight's speeches. Here's how.\n\nA Florida man famous for his deep tan, outsized lifestyle and lucrative knack for blending entertainment and reality will speak at the Republican National Convention Thursday night.\n\nHulk Hogan, the longtime pro wrestler whose real name is Terry Bollea, is on the recently released roster of speakers for the convention's final night, slated to speak in the run up to former President Donald Trump's address.\n\nThe official RNC program identifies Hulk Hogan as a \"professional entertainer and wrestler.\" He was also involved in a momentous legal case in the media world: His lawsuit against Gawker Media resulted in a $140 million jury award after the company published a sex tape featuring Bollea in 2015. An ensuing settlement sent the company and its founder into bankruptcy.\n\nAfter the sex tape emerged, there was abrupt fallout for Hulk Hogan: World Wrestling Entertainment spiked its contract with him over reports that he used racist language in the sex tape.\n\nIt may seem unexpected, but Hulk Hogan's prominent role at this year's RNC is another sign of the influence of billionaire Peter Thiel -- who bankrolled Hogan's fight against Gawker, and who has more recently been a key patron of Trump's new vice presidential pick, Sen. J.D. Vance.\n\nHogan is slated to speak sometime between 7:30 and 8 p.m. CT. He's bookended by two speakers that the RNC program identifies as \"everyday Americans.\"\n\nThose speakers are Carrie Ruiz, who is the general manager of golf at Trump National Doral in Miami; and Annette Albright of North Carolina, who lost her race last fall for an at-large seat on the Charlotte-Mecklenburg Board of Education.\n\nLoading...\n\nAlbright drew notice in that nonpartisan election after she and other candidates were accused of being \"Trojan horse Republicans,\" as member station WFAE reported.\n\nWWE is a professional wrestling promotion and media company, known for its scripted feats, ringside drama and zealous showmanship.\n\nVince McMahon bought an earlier version of the company in 1982, and, along with his wife Linda McMahon, is credited with bringing its unique blend of wrestling and entertainment into the mainstream. One of WWE's first -- and most enduring -- main attractions was none other than Hogan.\n\nTrump also had a hand in WWE's rise, hosting the fourth and fifth Wrestlemania events. And it was Trump's Apprentice catchphrase, \"You're fired,\" that a suited-up McMahon would shout in the ring. Trump has appeared at numerous WWE events over the years, including as a guest ring announcer and on-screen talent.\n\nTrump \"became part of some of the most compelling and highest-rated storylines in the company's history,\" McMahon said on the RNC stage. That includes in 2007 when Trump shaved McMahon's head.\n\nLinda McMahon left the company for politics, serving as Trump's small business administrator from 2017 to 2019 before leaving to join a pro-Trump super PAC.\n\nVince resigned from his leadership role at the company in January after a former employee filed a lawsuit accusing him of sexually assaulting her in the workplace, sex trafficking and pressuring her into threesomes. That lawsuit was paused earlier this year at the request of the U.S. Justice Department.\n\nThe Ultimate Fighting Championship (UFC), in contrast, is a mixed martial arts promotion company. It came on the scene in 1993, but wasn't a hit right away. In the early 2000s, Trump let UFC's new president, Dana White, use his Atlantic City casino. {"uri": "8233911152", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "17:30:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T17:30:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T17:18:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/entertainment/hulk-hogan-president-why-1998-171500034.html", "title": "Hulk Hogan for President? Why his 1998 publicity stunt backfired", "body": "Walrus-moustached wrestling icon Hulk Hogan took the idea of a rip-roaring good time to the limit at the national convention of Donald Trump's Republican party this week. Standing at the podium on Thursday, he roared, then ripped open his shirt to reveal a second shirt bearing Trump's name. \"Let Trumpmania run wild, brother,\" said Hogan, hype-man to the former President ahead of Trump's address that evening. \"Let Trumpmania rule again! Let Trumpmania make America great again!\"\n\nHogan's heroics in Wisconsin have have generated international headlines but for long-time followers of this mainstay of Nineties wrestling, the display may have carried a hint of d\u00e9j\u00e0 vu. Hogan, after all, attempted much the same stunt 26 years ago at Nassau County Memorial Coliseum on Long Island. On November 9, 1998, flanked by \"secret service\" agents in dark suits and wearing his full wrestling kit, \"Hollywood\" Hogan stomped into the ring and, amid a riot of red, white and blue confetti, addressed the sold-out audience at the World Champion Wrestling \"Nitro\" event.\n\n\"If I can get America behind me... we shall turn the page, we shall give America a brand new start,\" said Hogan, striking the same beats of bull-headed triumphalism he would summon when introducing Trump. \"All my people that love America shall take us into the new millennium on a brand new start. I am here not only to serve but to protect my country.\"\n\nFans bawled their approval - but did they know what they were cheering? His ambitions would soon be spelt out. Hogan, the biggest force in wrestling, was announcing his run for the 2000 Presidential election campaign. Mr Hollywood was going to Washington.\n\nThree weeks later, Hogan - real name Terry Gene Bollea - clarified his plans during an appearance on a Thanksgiving night edition of Jay Leno's Tonight Show. He confirmed he was retiring from wrestling and putting on hold the movie career that had earned him the \"Hollywood\" nickname and had seen him star in blockbusters such as Three Ninjas, Mr Nanny and Suburban Commando.\n\n\"I had to come to the crossroads here,\" he told Leno. \"I've accomplished everything I wanted to do in wrestling. My family is secure. I've had a great career. I wanted to come on your show tonight and officially announce my retirement.\"\n\nLeno - who presumably had missed the announcement at Nassau County Coliseum - looked shocked. \"All good things must come to an end. I had a great career,\" continued Hogan. \"The fans have been great. I love you guys and thanks for sticking with me. And this really helps me segue into being the next President of the United States.\"\n\nHogan didn't have many specific policies to share with viewers - though he received a cheer when he announced one of the first things he would do if elected would be to institute a federal flat tax. That got a huge yell. The people were on his side.\n\nThe idea of a human bendy toy such as Hulk Hogan seeking the Presidency seems ludicrous in 2024. In 1998, it was genuinely plausible. One of Hogan's rivals, Jesse \"The Body\" Ventura, had already started what would become a successful run for Governor of Minnesota. Five years later, another Hollywood action star, Arnold Schwarzenegger, would use Leno's talk show to announce he was running for governor of California. Hulk Hogan fancying a tilt at the White House might have been a surprise, but it wasn't a joke.\n\nOr at least that is what Leno and his audience thought. However, it would quickly become apparent that Hogan's designs were not on the Oval Office but on boosting his profile in wrestling. He didn't make any further TV appearances to plug his candidacy, and he certainly didn't hold any campaign rallies. It was all just a publicity stunt to hype the next WCW event in January 1999.\n\nThe WCW needed the exposure. Established in 1988 by CNN's Ted Turner as a rival to the all-powerful WWF (later the WWE), it had enjoyed a brief period of popularity - but by the late 1990s, its profile was on the slide, despite the involvement of Hogan. The WCW needed the ineffable Hulk to put it in the spotlight once again.\n\nIt helped that Hogan talked a good game. Criticised by Ventura for riding on his coattails, he would later dismiss his competitor as \"a very small minnow in a big lake\".\n\n\"We all know the difference between John Wayne and an extra who gets a little part,\" he told radio interviewer Todd Alan Clem (aka Bubba The Love Sponge). \"We all know the difference between Jesse The Body Ventura and Hollywood Hulk Hogan.\"\n\nHe also claimed to have received support from Willie Nelson and Ted Turner. \"We want a real America,\" he said. \"Not one of the plastic politicians.\"\n\nHogan's heart may never have been in the Presidential race, but he nonetheless felt he had a chance. His campaign manager, WCW President Eric Bischoff, later pointed to a poll in Atlanta which he said showed that, had he gone up against Bill Clinton or Al Gore, Hogan would have won 61 per cent of the vote.\n\nStill, there was widespread scepticism within wrestling. An early 1999 edition of The Wrestler magazine openly queried how serious he was, with the headline, \"Hogan's Retirement: White House or White Lie?\"\n\nBy the time The Wrestler hit the shelves, that question had already been answered. On January 4 1999, Hogan made a surprise appearance at the WCW Monday Nitro event, where he tangled with WCW champion Kevin Nash, felling the younger wrestler with a single prod of his finger - what become known as \"the finger poke of doom\".\n\nThe square-off was immediately notorious - not because it undermined Hogan's claim to have retired but because of the ludicrous sight of a finger-prod felling the six-foot-10 inch tall Nash. So absurd was the stunt not even American wrestling fans could swallow it - the New York Post said the incident was \"widely considered the beginning of the end for WCW\", which was acquired by the WWE in 2001.\n\nHogan went back to his day job but never formally renounced his presidential campaign. In late 1999, appearing on Larry King Live, he suggested he might still run. \" It's something that's not out of the question because with everybody having a different agenda and everybody owing everybody something in the political arena, it would be nice to have somebody that could put America first,\" he said. \"The way I look at it, if Jesse Ventura could become governor of Minnesota, I mean, I basically beat Jesse at everything he's done anyway in his life, so I might as well run for the President.\"\n\nThis was just more hot air - though it fell far short of the smoke he blew at Donald Trump's RNC appearance this week. Hogan has since had his ups and downs: in 2015 he issued a public apology after he was caught using the \"n\" word in a leaked sex tape. But he was visibly having the time of his life as Trump's cheerleader. After a lifetime of pretend-tossing people around the ring, the thrill he felt at joining Trump in a real-life political cage fight was there for the whole world to see.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8232760805", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "03:24:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T03:24:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T03:23:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.kpbs.org/news/politics/2024/07/18/hulk-hogan-linda-mcmahon-and-dana-white-speak-in-support-of-trump-on-the-last-night-of-the-rnc", "title": "Hulk Hogan, Linda McMahon and Dana White speak in support of Trump on the last night of the RNC", "body": "For more updates from the 2024 Republican National Convention in Milwaukee, head to the NPR Network's live updates page. Plus: You can watch live video coverage from NPR of tonight's speeches. Here's how.\n\nA Florida man famous for his deep tan, outsized lifestyle and lucrative knack for blending entertainment and reality will speak at the Republican National Convention Thursday night.\n\nHulk Hogan, the longtime pro wrestler whose real name is Terry Bollea, is on the recently released roster of speakers for the convention's final night, slated to speak in the run up to former President Donald Trump's address.\n\nHogan, who has been known to make a dramatic entrance in the ring, walked onstage against a montage of videos and photos of himself in various patriotic poses.\n\nHe took to the podium wearing a red bandana and sunglasses on his head, gesturing to the crowd that he couldn't hear their chants of \"USA.\"\n\nThe retired professional wrestler said the \"vibe was so intense, the energy was so crazy, it felt like maybe I was gonna press that no-good stinky giant over my head and slam him into the mat, brother.\"\n\nThe official RNC program identifies Hulk Hogan as a \"professional entertainer and wrestler.\" He was also involved in a momentous legal case in the media world: His lawsuit against Gawker Media resulted in a $140 million jury award after the company published a sex tape featuring Bollea in 2015. An ensuing settlement sent the company and its founder into bankruptcy.\n\nAfter the sex tape emerged, there was abrupt fallout for Hulk Hogan: World Wrestling Entertainment spiked its contract with him over reports that he used racist language in the sex tape.\n\nIt may seem unexpected, but Hulk Hogan's prominent role at this year's RNC is another sign of the influence of billionaire Peter Thiel -- who bankrolled Hogan's fight against Gawker, and who has more recently been a key patron of Trump's new vice presidential pick, Sen. J.D. Vance.\n\nHogan remarkes were bookended by two speakers that the RNC program identifies as \"everyday Americans.\"\n\nCarrie Ruiz, who is the general manager of golf at Trump National Doral in Miami; and Annette Albright of North Carolina, who lost her race last fall for an at-large seat on the Charlotte-Mecklenburg Board of Education.\n\nLoading...\n\nAlbright drew notice in that nonpartisan election after she and other candidates were accused of being \"Trojan horse Republicans,\" as member station WFAE reported.\n\nWWE is a professional wrestling promotion and media company, known for its scripted feats, ringside drama and zealous showmanship.\n\nVince McMahon bought an earlier version of the company in 1982, and, along with his wife Linda McMahon, is credited with bringing its unique blend of wrestling and entertainment into the mainstream. One of WWE's first -- and most enduring -- main attractions was none other than Hogan.\n\nTrump also had a hand in WWE's rise, hosting the fourth and fifth Wrestlemania events. And it was Trump's Apprentice catchphrase, \"You're fired,\" that a suited-up McMahon would shout in the ring. Trump has appeared at numerous WWE events over the years, including as a guest ring announcer and on-screen talent.\n\nTrump \"became part of some of the most compelling and highest-rated storylines in the company's history,\" McMahon said on the RNC stage. That includes in 2007 when Trump shaved McMahon's head.\n\nLinda McMahon left the company for politics, serving as Trump's small business administrator from 2017 to 2019 before leaving to join a pro-Trump super PAC.\n\nVince resigned from his leadership role at the company in January after a former employee filed a lawsuit accusing him of sexually assaulting her in the workplace, sex trafficking and pressuring her into threesomes. That lawsuit was paused earlier this year at the request of the U.S. Justice Department.\n\nThe Ultimate Fighting Championship (UFC), in contrast, is a mixed martial arts promotion company. It came on the scene in 1993, but wasn't a hit right away. In the early 2000s, Trump let UFC's new president, Dana White, use his Atlantic City casino. His endorsement helped the company become the world's largest MMA promotion, as of 2023.", "source": {"uri": "kpbs.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "KPBS"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8232696693", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "02:11:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T02:11:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T02:10:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.mediaite.com/tv/watch-hulk-hogan-brings-down-the-rnc-house-by-ripping-off-his-shirt-to-reveal-maga-wear/", "title": "WATCH: Hulk Hogan Brings Down the RNC House by Ripping Off His Shirt to Reveal MAGA-Wear", "body": "Retired professional wrestler Hulk Hogan brought down the house at the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee on Thursday night, tearing off his shirt to reveal a MAGA cutoff and his support for former President Donald Trump at the GOP convention.\n\nDuring the fourth and final night of the event and just before Trump was set to accept the Republican Party's nomination for president for the third consecutive election, Hogan took to a podium to declare his support for the country's 45th president.\n\nThe 70-year-old - whose real name is Terry Bollea - began his speech with a calm demeanor. But his utterances of his longtime catchphrase \"brother\" ticked up as he praised Trump and called on the restoration of law and order in the country.\n\n\"What happened last week when they took a shot at my hero and they tried to kill the next president of the United States, I said, 'Enough was enough!\" Hogan shouted in a reference to the assassination attempt against Trump last Saturday in Pennsylvania.\n\nAs the wrestler began to raise his voice, he removed his blazer, ripped a black T-shirt apart at the chest, and revealed a Trump/Vance cutoff shirt.\n\nHogan concluded, \"I said, 'Let Trump-a-Mania run wild, brother! Let Trump-a-Mania rule again! let Trump-a-Mania make America great again!\"\n\nFox News cameras followed Trump's reaction to the speech. {"uri": "2024-07-426736047", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "06:05:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T06:05:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T05:56:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/4781271-donald-trump-rnc-joe-biden-jd-vance/", "title": "Trump comes out fighting after rally shooting: 5 takeaways from RNC's last night", "body": "Former President Trump turned the 2024 Republican National Convention into a campaign rally in his first speech since surviving an assassination attempt, claiming God was on his side during the shooting and calling for his party to unify to \"save this country.\"\n\nTrump divulged the details of his near-death experience as he addressed thousands in attendance in Milwaukee and formally accepted the GOP presidential nomination.\n\nHere are the five big takeaways from the last night of the convention:\n\nTrump went into detail about assassination\n\nAfter four days of suspense, Trump opened his convention-capping speech by telling the story of his experience during the attempted assassination at his Saturday rally in Pennsylvania, where gunman grazed his ear with a bullet, killed one rally attendee and wounded two others.\n\n\"As you already know, the assassin's bullet came within a quarter of an inch of taking my life. So many people have asked me: 'What happened? Tell us what happened, please,'\" Trump said.\n\nHe promised to tell the crowd \"exactly what happened\" but swore that he would \"never\" share it a second time \"because it's actually too painful to tell.\"\n\nTrump waxed poetic about the \"warm, beautiful day in the early evening\" and the \"cheering\" crowd in Pennsylvania, which then he said was cut off by a \"loud, whizzing sound\" and the feeling of the bullet hitting his ear \"really, really hard.\"\n\nTrump was wearing a white bandage over the ear that had been wounded in the incident. In the crowd, some RNC attendees sported similar ear coverings, which one woman said was done \"in solidarity\" with the former president.\n\nThough he described a \"terrible evening\" and a tense brush with death as \"many bullets\" were fired, he said he felt \"serene.\" He thanked God for his survival and said it was \"probably\" a \"providential moment.\"\n\nThe crowd was riveted by Trump's tale and broke into chants of \"fight\" as the now-viral photo of the former president surrounded by Secret Service agents and raising his fist in the air flashed on the screen behind him.\n\nTrump was his old self\n\nEarlier speakers had seemed to lay the groundwork for a softer version of Trump to take the stage.\n\nA Wednesday night appearance from Trump's granddaughter, Kai Madison Trump, presented the former president as a \"normal grandpa\" who \"gives us candy and soda when our parents aren't looking\" and \"always wants to know how we're doing in school.\"\n\nOn Thursday, Linda McMahon, who served as Trump's small business administrator, shared an anecdote about Trump and his 4-year-old granddaughter at his Mar-a-Lago residence, in which he \"smiled with the love that only a grandfather could have given\" when the girl \"mussed his hair.\"\n\nMcMahon acknowledged the anecdote was \"probably not the typical Donald Trump story\" and said the former president was \"a good man\" with \"the heart of a lion and the soul of a warrior.\"\n\nBut the Trump who spoke Thursday night was the same one seen at every rally since he launched his campaign in 2015.\n\nText of the speech released ahead of time mostly focused on Trump's plans for a potential second term and discussions about the problems he views as facing the country, but he strayed from the planned remarks frequently, pivoting instead to praise allies and attack his enemies.\n\nEven though the script as written did not include President Biden's name, Trump seemingly couldn't resist taking a direct jab at his opponent, saying that \"if you took the 10 worst presidents in the history of the United States ... added them up, they will not have done the damage that Biden has done.\"\n\nHe also dinged former Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.), calling her \"crazy Nancy\" and yielding boos from the audience toward her. A spokesperson for Pelosi later responded that Trump did not take a \"new tone\" as some expected him to and is the same candidate that he was.\n\nTrump also slammed the leader of United Auto Workers for jobs being sent abroad to countries like China, saying he should be \"ashamed\" and \"fired.\"\n\nAt the same time, Trump leaned into the \"unity\" theme of the week, especially toward the end of his speech when he was back on script, saying that the country's \"destiny\" will be out of reach if people spend their energy fighting each other.\n\n\"We must instead take that energy and use it to realize our country's true potential -- and write our own thrilling chapter of the American story,\" he said.\n\nThe event was like a rock concert\n\nThe crowd was electric throughout Thursday night's lineup, which included celebrity appearances from music star Kid Rock, fight promoter Dana White and wrestling legend Hulk Hogan.\n\nHogan, whose legal name is Terry Bollea, prompted chants of \"USA\" during remarks that praised Trump and his newly-named running mate, Ohio Sen. JD Vance, as \"the greatest tag team of my life.\"\n\nHe also pointed out the raucous, celebratory crowd.\n\n\"When I came here tonight, there was so much energy in this room, I thought maybe I was in Madison Square Garden getting ready to win another title,\" Hogan said. \"But what I found out was I was in a room full of real Americans, brother.\"\n\nKid Rock, meanwhile, had the audience chanting \"fight\" and \"Trump\" as he sang his song \"American Bad Ass.\"\n\nAt the end of the night, Trump made a flashy entrance to a live performance of Lee Greenwood's \"God Bless the U.S.A.\" and wandered the stage, waving at the audience and clapping his hands as the song wrapped up before taking the podium.\n\nThe night ended in a cinematic drop of reportedly more than 100,000 red, white, blue and gold balloons as Trump's family joined him on stage and the Fiserv Forum crowd went wild.\n\nHulk Hogan almost stole the spotlight\n\nIt's a tall task to outshine Trump, but Hogan almost did it.\n\nThe wrestler brought the house down in Milwaukee while delivering a speech praising the former president.\n\nThe crowd burst into a \"USA\" chant as soon as Hogan came to the stage.\n\nBut perhaps the most thrilling moment during his appearance came when the wrestling legend tore his shirt off while speaking to the crowd, unleashing an almost deafening collective roar from the audience.\n\n\"When they tried to kill the next president of the United States, enough was enough, and I said let Trumpamania run wild, brother,\" he said to thunderous applause, in a play on the catchphrase \"Hulkamania.\"\n\nHogan later sat in Trump's box with the former president's family, and Trump himself appeared to acknowledge how much Hogan energized the crowd.\n\n\"How about the Hulkster?\" Trump asked later in the night, which attendees responded to with cheers.\n\nBiden's woes were an undercurrent\n\nAs Republicans reveled in Trump's first post-shooting speech and celebrated his formal acceptance of the party nomination, Democrats continued to see internal battles around Biden and their 2024 ticket.\n\nIn the middle of the RNC, Montana Sen. Jon Tester became the second Democratic senator to call on Biden to withdraw from the presidential race.\n\nTester, a vulnerable Democrat running for reelection in a red state, said he appreciates the incumbent's \"commitment to public service and our country,\" but that Biden \"should not seek reelection to another term.\"\n\nThe Montana senator's move added to ongoing Democratic drama that had been dulled slightly in the wake of the rally shooting but that was renewed when more prominent party names piled on earlier this week.\n\nOn Wednesday, Rep. Adam Schiff (D-Calif.) shared \"serious concerns\" about Biden's ability to beat Trump in November and Rep. Jim Costa (D-Calif.) joined the calls, saying it's time for Biden to \"pass the torch.\"\n\nTrump brought up Biden by name just once in his RNC speech -- though the reference was notably not in the remarks that were released ahead of time.\n\n\"Only gonna use the term once, Biden. I'm not gonna use the name anymore. Just one time,\" Trump said, and though his speech went after the administration, he avoided talk of the drama playing out across the aisle.\n\nTalk is ramping up about Vice President Kamala Harris potentially replacing her boss at the top of the ticket, and Democratic Party insiders are murmuring that a decision about Biden's political future could come in a matter of days as their own August convention nears.", "source": {"uri": "thehill.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Hill"}, "authors": [{"uri": "jared_gans@thehill.com", "name": "Jared Gans", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, At 70, Hogan recently mentioned on \"Fox & Friends\" that he is considering entering politics now that he has retired from wrestling. \"We need somebody in there that's got some common sense,\" Hogan said. \"So, if you need a president or vice president, I'll volunteer and take this country over, and I'll rule with an iron fist, a flat tax - nothing but common sense. I know right from wrong, brother,\" he added.\n\nThe final night of the convention traditionally draws the highest viewership, making it the most coveted time slot for speakers. This year's event is notable for the absence of past GOP stalwarts, including former House Speaker Paul Ryan and Trump's former vice president, Mike Pence, neither of whom are endorsing the GOP nominee. The only other living former Republican president, George W. Bush, last addressed a GOP convention remotely from the White House in 2008.\n\nOther speakers include Tucker Carlson, Trump attorney Alina Habba, former Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, and Franklin Graham. {"uri": "2024-07-426633763", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "03:27:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T03:27:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T21:37:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2024/jul/18/hulk-hogan-climbs-political-ring-his-hero-donald-t/", "title": "The Hulkster climbs into the political ring for his 'hero' Trump at RNC", "body": "MILWAUKEE -- Hulkamania ran wild Thursday evening at the Republican National Convention.\n\nProfessional wrestling legend Hulk Hogan brought down the house at Fiserv Forum here in a vivid speech that drew heavily on his wrestling persona and alluding to such 1980s artifacts as his hit record \"I Am A Real American.\"\n\n\"When Donald J. Trump becomes the president of the United States, all the real Americans are going to be nicknamed Trumpites because all the Trumpites are going to be running wild for four years,\" the Hulkster said.\n\n\"So with the power of Donald J. Trump and all the Trumpites running wild, America is going to get back on track, and like Donald J. Trump said, America is going to be great again,\" he said.\n\nHis speech was peppered with callbacks and turns of phrase referencing his wrestling career during the 1980s.\n\nMr. Hogan referred in his speech to \"savages,\" \"warriors\" and \"giants,\" alluding to the names of such rivals and allies -- it was pro wrestling, after all -- as Randy Savage, the Ultimate Warrior and Andre the Giant.\n\nMimicking his signature move, Hogan tore away his shirt to reveal a Trump Vance muscle-shirt underneath and sent the crowd into a frenzy by flexing in the exact poses he did when was World Wrestling Federation champion.\n\nHe closed out his speech by giving notice to liberals and riffing off his signature warning to his opponents back then.\n\n\"And what you gonna do when Donald Trump and all the Trumpamaniacs run wild on you!\" he said.\n\nThere is precedent for speakers like the Hulkster, who briefly reminded the audience that his real name is Terry Bollea.\n\nNational conventions have included a variety of quasi-surprises over the years.\n\nActor Clint Eastwood assumed the role at the 2012 convention and scored an array of headlines after addressing an empty chair that represented President Obama.\n\nBefore his speech, Mr. Hogan said he \"got tired of remaining silent\" as he watched the increasing chaos at the border, and inflation raise the cost of groceries and gas.\n\n\"When they took a shot at my hero Donald Trump, I realized that I couldn't be silent any more,\" he said on Fox News. \"You know, I had to step up. I had to be a real American just like all these real Americans here and Donald Trump.\"\n\nHe said he was giddy about vouching for his friend.\n\n\"This is going to be like body-slamming the Giant at WrestleMania,\" he said then, a line he repeated during the Thursday evening speech.\n\nHogan addressed delegates on the final day of the convention and served as part of the warm-up act for Mr. Trump.\n\nMr. Trump has dabbled in the art of wrestling himself.\n\nWearing his signature shirt and tie, he slammed World Wrestling Federation CEO Vince McMahon to the group during the Battle of the Billionaires at WrestleMania 23 in 2007 in Detroit.\n\nMr. Hogan was at the center of a 2013 legal dispute over a sex tape that forced the owners of the liberal Gawker website to file for bankruptcy. Peter Thiel, who helped finance the rise of Mr. Trump's vice presidential nominee J.D. Vance, helped bankroll Mr. Hogan's lawsuit.\n\nThe final speaker lineup also included Dana White, CEO of the UFC, and Linda McMahon, head of the Small Business Administration in the Trump White House and former head of World Wrestling Entertainment.\n\nMr. Hogan, 70, brought professional wrestling to the center of American popular culture in the 1980s with his charismatic persona, fabled leg drop, \"24-inch python\" biceps and for sending his fans into a frenzy with a walkout that included musician Rick Derringer's song \"Real American.\"\n\n\"I am a real American,\" the lyrics say. \"Fight for the rights of every man. I am a real American. Fight for what's right! {"uri": "8233422250", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "11:39:29", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T11:39:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T11:39:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/3am/celebrity-news/russell-brands-right-wing-transformation-33280803", "title": "Russell Brand's right-wing transformation complete as he backs Trump at GOP bash", "body": "From Labour supporter to GOP guest: Russell Brand attends Republican National Convention amid controversy\n\nRussell Brand is seemingly getting involved in American politics ahead of the election across the pond later this year.\n\nNewly-baptised Brand, 49, rubbed shoulders with the likes of actor Jason Aldean and Hulk Hogan at the Republican National Convention at the Fiserv Forum on Thursday, as former President Donald Trump accepted his party's presidential nomination.\n\nBrand mingling with Republican figures is a far cry from the days when the dad-of-four used to poke fun at the GOP (Grand Old Party). The former TV star, who once identified as left-wing and urged Britons to vote for the Labour Party, sparked an outrage in September 2008 when he called the then President George W. Bush a \"re***ded cowboy\" at the MTV Video Music Awards.\n\nThe former Big Brother's Big Mouth host then begged Americans to elect Democrat candidate Barack Obama as their President in the following November. But it looks like Brand has well and truly switched allegiances and found new common ground with the Republican Party.\n\nBrand has kept a low-profile in the UK since September, when he found himself at the centre of numerous allegations of rape, assault and emotional abuse that are said to have taken place between 2006 and 2013. Brand vehemently denied all the allegations at the time and still does to this day.\n\nStepping out in American on Thursday, Brand donned a pair of dark sunglasses, a crucifix necklace and low-cut black shirt as he attended the fourth day of the Republican National Convention at the Fiserv Forum in Milwaukee, Wisconsin. The British celebrity was amongst delegates, politicians, and the Republican faithful as they showed their support for Donald Trump, 78, and his bid to return to the White House.\n\nTrump, who will be up against President Joe Biden when Americans head to the polls later this year, was rushed offstage after shots were fired at his rally in Butler over the weekend. Trump was roughly six minutes into a speech in Butler when he suddenly reached for the side of his face as gunfire rang out. He then crouched and ran for cover before being rushed off the stage surrounded by Secret Service agents. Blood could be seen on his face and ear and the former US president has been sporting a fetching white bandage right ear ever since.\n\nAt the Republican National Convention on Thursday, Hulk Hogan ripped his shirt off during a speech as he emotionally showed professed his love for Trump. The veteran wrestler - who has known the former US President for more than 35 years - took to the stage to speak at the event after Trump was confirmed as the party's official nominee for the US election in November.\n\nHe drove the crowd wild by taking off his suit jacket and ripping off a tank top to reveal a red Trump/Vance shirt underneath. After coming on stage to the tune of his wrestling theme Real American, he pumped the audience up with his catchphrase, saying: \"Well, let me tell you something brother!\" before referencing the assassination attempt on Trump in Pennsylvania last Saturday when a gun man opened fire on the politician leaving Trump with a wounded ear and killing a crowd-member.\n\nHogan continued: \"What happened last week ...when they took a shot at my hero ....They tried to kill the greatest president of the United States. Enough was enough!!\" He also recalled winning a wrestling world title in front of keen fan Trump and went on to pledge his support to his old friend, adding: \"Over my career, I've been in the ring with some of the biggest, some of the baddest dudes on the planet, and I've squared off against warriors, ooh yeah, savages.\n\n\"And I've even, like I said, body-slammed giants in the middle of the ring. And I know tough guys, but let me tell you something, brother, Donald Trump is the toughest of them all. All you criminals, all you lowlifes, all you scumbags ... Whatcha gonna do when Donald Trump and all the Trumpamaniacs run wild on you, brother?\"\n\nHogan added: \"As as an entertainer, I tried to stay out of politics, but after everything that's happened to our country over the past four years and everything that happened last weekend [the assassination attempt], I can no longer be silent. I'm here tonight because I want the world to know that Donald Trump is a real American hero, and I'm proud to support my hero as the next president of this United States. I've known that man for over 35 years, and he's always been the biggest patriot, and he still is. He's always told you exactly what he thought, and he still does brother. Let Trump-O-Mania rule again, let Trump-O-Mania make America great again!\"\n\nTrump - who is a longtime wrestling fan and has long been involved with the WWE - was seen blowing Hogan a kiss as he finished his speech and later gave him a shout-out as he officially accepted the Republican nomination. He said of Hogan: \"I know about entertainment, but when he used to lift a 350 pound man over his shoulders and then bench press him two rows into the audience, I said, that maybe entertainment, but he is one strong son-of-a-gun.\"\n\nTrump previously hosted WWE's flagship event WrestleMania IV and WrestleMania V at his Trump Plaza in Atlantic City, New Jersey and was a regular ringside. He also took part in 2007's WrestleMania 23 - which was dubbed 'Battle of the Billionaires' - as Trump chose a champion fighter to take on a wrestler chosen by WWE Chairman Vince McMahon with the loser being forced to shave his head.\n\nTrump won and got to keep his famous head of hair and was later seen shaving McMahon's head. The reality TV star-turned-politician was inducted into the WWE Hall of Fame in 2013 with his old foe McMahon doing the honours.\n\nFollow Mirror Celebs on TikTok , Snapchat , Instagram , Twitter , All of that slowly and surely moved me towards where I'm at now.\"\n\nPart of Hogan's motivation to get fit was to show other men of a similar age that it's never too late to work on yourself.\n\nHe added: \"I didn't think this kind of transformation was possible at this stage in my life.\n\n\"I'm 69 years old, but I feel like I'm 39. And it's not just the physical effects - it's the mindset I have now.\n\n\"My advice for anyone else looking to make a change later in life is 'just get back to the dance'. Do whatever it takes to get back to who you are and what you love.\"\n\nIt became clear Hogan has been working hard in the gym ever since when he made a cameo at the Republican National Convention on Thursday evening.\n\nSpeaking in support of Donald Trump, he repeatedly made wrestling references whilst giving a speech backing Trump in his attempt to win a second term as United States president.\n\nHogan sparked delight among those in attendance when he ripped off his shirt in trademark fashion, revealing a red one underneath displaying his support for Trump.\n\nThe top didn't come off entirely, but Hogan's bulging biceps were on full display as he flexed during his show-stealing performance at the political meeting.\n\nIt just goes to show that age really is just a number for Let Trumpamania rule again! Let Trumpamania make America great again!\"\n\nThe former president has had ties to the wrestling industry for decades and has participated in WWE events, which is how he and Hogan interacted, The New York Times reported. {"uri": "8233403995", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "11:27:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T11:27:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T11:26:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5333333611488342, "url": "https://conservativeangle.com/trump-comes-out-fighting-after-rally-shooting-5-takeaways-from-rncs-last-night/", "title": "Trump comes out fighting after rally shooting: 5 takeaways from RNC's last night - Conservative Angle", "body": "Former President Trump turned the 2024 Republican National Convention into a campaign rally in his first speech since surviving an assassination attempt, claiming God was on his side during the shooting and calling for his party to unify to \"save this country.\"\n\nTrump divulged the details of his near-death experience as he addressed thousands in attendance in Milwaukee and formally accepted the GOP presidential nomination.\n\nHere are the five big takeaways from the last night of the convention:\n\nAfter four days of suspense, Trump opened his convention-capping speech by telling the story of his experience during the attempted assassination at his Saturday rally in Pennsylvania, where gunman grazed his ear with a bullet, killed one rally attendee and wounded two others.\n\n\"As you already know, the assassin's bullet came within a quarter of an inch of taking my life. So many people have asked me: 'What happened? Tell us what happened, please,'\" Trump said.\n\nHe promised to tell the crowd \"exactly what happened\" but swore that he would \"never\" share it a second time \"because it's actually too painful to tell.\"\n\nTrump waxed poetic about the \"warm, beautiful day in the early evening\" and the \"cheering\" crowd in Pennsylvania, which then he said was cut off by a \"loud, whizzing sound\" and the feeling of the bullet hitting his ear \"really, really hard.\"\n\nTrump was wearing a white bandage over the ear that had been wounded in the incident. In the crowd, some RNC attendees sported similar ear coverings, which one woman said was done \"in solidarity\" with the former president.\n\nThough he described a \"terrible evening\" and a tense brush with death as \"many bullets\" were fired, he said he felt \"serene.\" He thanked God for his survival and said it was \"probably\" a \"providential moment.\"\n\nThe crowd was riveted by Trump's tale and broke into chants of \"fight\" as the now-viral photo of the former president surrounded by Secret Service agents and raising his fist in the air flashed on the screen behind him.\n\nEarlier speakers had seemed to lay the groundwork for a softer version of Trump to take the stage.\n\nA Wednesday night appearance from Trump's granddaughter, Kai Madison Trump, presented the former president as a \"normal grandpa\" who \"gives us candy and soda when our parents aren't looking\" and \"always wants to know how we're doing in school.\"\n\nOn Thursday, Linda McMahon, who served as Trump's small business administrator, shared an anecdote about Trump and his 4-year-old granddaughter at his Mar-a-Lago residence, in which he \"smiled with the love that only a grandfather could have given\" when the girl \"mussed his hair.\"\n\nMcMahon acknowledged the anecdote was \"probably not the typical Donald Trump story\" and said the former president was \"a good man\" with \"the heart of a lion and the soul of a warrior.\"\n\nBut the Trump who spoke Thursday night was the same one seen at every rally since he launched his campaign in 2015.\n\nText of the speech released ahead of time mostly focused on Trump's plans for a potential second term and discussions about the problems he views as facing the country, but he strayed from the planned remarks frequently, pivoting instead to praise allies and attack his enemies.\n\nEven though the script as written did not include President Biden's name, Trump seemingly couldn't resist taking a direct jab at his opponent, saying that \"if you took the 10 worst presidents in the history of the United States ... added them up, they will not have done the damage that Biden has done.\"\n\nHe also dinged former Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.), calling her \"crazy Nancy\" and yielding boos from the audience toward her. A spokesperson for Pelosi later responded that Trump did not take a \"new tone\" as some expected him to and is the same candidate that he was.\n\nTrump also slammed the leader of United Auto Workers for jobs being sent abroad to countries like China, saying he should be \"ashamed\" and \"fired.\"\n\nAt the same time, Trump leaned into the \"unity\" theme of the week, especially toward the end of his speech when he was back on script, saying that the country's \"destiny\" will be out of reach if people spend their energy fighting each other.\n\n\"We must instead take that energy and use it to realize our country's true potential -- and write our own thrilling chapter of the American story,\" he said.\n\nThe crowd was electric throughout Thursday night's lineup, which included celebrity appearances from music star Kid Rock, fight promoter Dana White and wrestling legend Hulk Hogan.\n\nHogan, whose legal name is Terry Bollea, prompted chants of \"USA\" during remarks that praised Trump and his newly-named running mate, Ohio Sen. JD Vance, as \"the greatest tag team of my life.\"\n\nHe also pointed out the raucous, celebratory crowd.\n\n\"When I came here tonight, there was so much energy in this room, I thought maybe I was in Madison Square Garden getting ready to win another title,\" Hogan said. \"But what I found out was I was in a room full of real Americans, brother.\"\n\nKid Rock, meanwhile, had the audience chanting \"fight\" and \"Trump\" as he sang his song \"American Bad Ass.\"\n\nAt the end of the night, Trump made a flashy entrance to a live performance of Lee Greenwood's \"God Bless the U.S.A.\" and wandered the stage, waving at the audience and clapping his hands as the song wrapped up before taking the podium.\n\nThe night ended in a cinematic drop of reportedly more than 100,000 red, white, blue and gold balloons as Trump's family joined him on stage and the Fiserv Forum crowd went wild.\n\nIt's a tall task to outshine Trump, but Hogan almost did it.\n\nThe wrestler brought the house down in Milwaukee while delivering a speech praising the former president.\n\nThe crowd burst into a \"USA\" chant as soon as Hogan came to the stage.\n\nBut perhaps the most thrilling moment during his appearance came when the wrestling legend tore his shirt off while speaking to the crowd, unleashing an almost deafening collective roar from the audience.\n\n\"When they tried to kill the next president of the United States, enough was enough, and I said let Trumpamania run wild, brother,\" he said to thunderous applause, in a play on the catchphrase \"Hulkamania.\"\n\nHogan later sat in Trump's box with the former president's family, and Trump himself appeared to acknowledge how much Hogan energized the crowd.\n\n\"How about the Hulkster?\" Trump asked later in the night, which attendees responded to with cheers.\n\nAs Republicans reveled in Trump's first post-shooting speech and celebrated his formal acceptance of the party nomination, Democrats continued to see internal battles around Biden and their 2024 ticket.\n\nIn the middle of the RNC, Montana Sen. Jon Tester became the second Democratic senator to call on Biden to withdraw from the presidential race.\n\nTester, a vulnerable Democrat running for reelection in a red state, said he appreciates the incumbent's \"commitment to public service and our country,\" but that Biden \"should not seek reelection to another term.\"\n\nThe Montana senator's move added to ongoing Democratic drama that had been dulled slightly in the wake of the rally shooting but that was renewed when more prominent party names piled on earlier this week.\n\nOn Wednesday, Rep. Adam Schiff (D-Calif.) shared \"serious concerns\" about Biden's ability to beat Trump in November and Rep. Jim Costa (D-Calif.) joined the calls, saying it's time for Biden to \"pass the torch.\"\n\nTrump brought up Biden by name just once in his RNC speech -- though the reference was notably not in the remarks that were released ahead of time.\n\n\"Only gonna use the term once, Biden. I'm not gonna use the name anymore. Just one time,\" Trump said, and though his speech went after the administration, he avoided talk of the drama playing out across the aisle.\n\nTalk is ramping up about Vice President Kamala Harris potentially replacing her boss at the top of the ticket, and Democratic Party insiders are murmuring that a decision about Biden's political future could come in a matter of days as their own August convention nears.", "source": {"uri": "conservativeangle.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Brigitte Gabriel"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8233380001", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "11:12:08", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T11:12:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T11:11:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.529411792755127, "url": "https://www.westernjournal.com/watch-hulk-hogan-tears-shirt-trump-live-air-iconic-moment-enough-enough/", "title": "Watch: Hulk Hogan Tears His Shirt for Trump Live on Air in Iconic Moment - 'ENOUGH WAS ENOUGH!'", "body": "Well, you can't say that the Republican National Convention of 2024 was like any other party convention, ever.\n\nNot that this was a bad thing. It won't be remembered like the Democratic National Convention in Chicago in 1968, where activist violence and political horse trading made for a memorable event for all the wrong reasons.\n\nIt won't be potentially remembered like, um, the Democratic National Convention in Chicago next month, where the specter of activist violence and political horse trading could make for a memorable event for all the wrong reasons.\n\nNo, the RNC in Milwaukee saw four nights of harmony, fun, solemnity, entertainment and, most of all, patriotism.\n\nThere were heartfelt tributes to the fallen firefighter who died Saturday trying to protect his family from bullets during the assassination attempt against former President Donald Trump. There was a powerful speech from Trump's running mate, Ohio Sen. J.D. Vance. There was a performance by Kid Rock.\n\nAnd, yes, there was even Hulk Hogan ripping his shirt off on stage in a fit of \"Trumpmania\" and declaring the GOP nominee his \"hero.\"\n\nHogan, legal name Terry G. Bollea, is best known for his professional wrestling persona -- which he didn't shed during his appearance on Thursday night in Milwaukee. According to The New York Times, while both he and Trump have had close ties to World Wrestling Entertainment for decades and even participated in events together, Hogan was undecided as to whom he would support in the election as recently as a month ago.\n\nThat changed after the assassination attempt in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\n\"When I saw him stand up with that fist in the air and the blood on his face -- as a warrior, as a leader -- I realized that's what America needs,\" Hogan told Fox News.\n\nHogan's speech contained similar sentiments.\n\n\"You know something, when I came here tonight, there was so much energy in this room, I felt maybe I was in Madison Square Garden getting ready to win another world title,\" he told the crowd. \"The vibe was so intense.\"\n\n\"The energy was so crazy, it felt like maybe I was gonna press that no-good sticky giant over my head and slam him through the mat, brother!\" he exclaimed, referencing his legendary, 1987 body-slam of the 7'4'', 500-pound wrestler Andr\u00e9 the Giant, who died in 1993.\n\n\"Over my career, I've been in the ring with some of the biggest, some of the baddest dudes on the planet, and I've squared off against warriors, ooh yeah, savages,\" he continued, referencing two more WWE legends -- the Ultimate Warrior and \"Macho Man\" Randy Savage.\n\n\"And I've even, like I said, body-slammed giants in the middle of the ring. And I know tough guys, but let me tell you something, brother, Donald Trump is the toughest of them all.\n\n\"All you criminals, all you lowlifes, all you scumbags ... Whatcha gonna do when Donald Trump and all the Trumpamaniacs run wild on you, brother?\"\n\nAnd then came the shirt-ripping moment:\n\n\"What happened last week, when they took a shot at my hero -- they tried to kill the greatest president of the United States!\" he yelled. \"Enough was enough!\"\n\nAnd with that, he did his trademark shirt-rip -- to reveal a Trump/Vance 2024 T-shirt:\n\nIn an interview with Fox News before the appearance, a noticeably calmer Hulk said the deteriorating state of the country is what got him to support Trump publicly.\n\n\"I got tired of remaining silent,\" Hulk said. \"I sat back and watched the borders collapse. I watched the economy collapse. I watched the price of gas, I watched the price of food, everything just do an upside down flip.\n\n\"And when they took a shot at my hero, Donald Trump, I realized I couldn't be silent any more.\"", "source": {"uri": "westernjournal.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Western Journal"}, "authors": [{"uri": "c_douglas_golden@westernjournal.com", "name": "C. But a video has recently resurfaced of the wrestler enjoying himself making fun of the former reality TV star.\n\nIn the video, which was posted to X (formerly Twitter) by PatriotTakes, Hogan walks viewers through how to do a proper impersonation of Trump. He notably mentioned that it was important to emphasize that a Trump impression requires not being \"cool\" and to \"turn your back on everyone.\"\n\n\"First thing we gotta do is get of anything that's cool,\" Hogan said, taking off his signature sunglasses. \"So sunglasses gotta go.\"\n\nREAD MORE: Fox News suffers body blow as billionaire spends millions to bolster defamation lawsuit\n\n\"Next thing we gotta do is turn our back to everybody or on everybody. So let me turn my back on everybody that's close to me,\" he continued, commenting on how his back \"looks like the Brooklyn Bridge, brother.\"\n\n\"So now that I got my back turned, I'm definitely in character. And in my opinion, Donald Trump, the first thing he would do, would be to pull out the comb. For the over! So we can get the comb... over, brother,\" Hogan said, putting a paper bag on top of his head in an imitation of Trump's hair.\n\n\"And now we pucker them little lips up,\" he added. \"So now I got the combover and I'm officially Trump-itized, Trump-a-mania runnin' wild with the combover -- oh wait a minute, there's a flap of wind covering the bald spot, hold on brother! Whoa, whoa whoa, God, turn the wind down, this is Donald Trump! Whoa, don't blow my hair up! -- Alright, now that I got the combover, the first that I'm gonna do is: 'Ivana, you're fired! Melania, you're fired! ... the new wife, you're f -- wait, I can't fire the new wife, she'll take the other half of my stuff!'\"\n\n\"Anyway, that's how you imitate Donald Trump, chump!\" Hogan said, blowing up the paper bag and popping it in his hands.\n\nREAD MORE: 'Not all peaches and cream': RNC stumped on how to 'soften' Trump's image at convention\n\nThe final night of the RNC, which is typically when the most high-profile speakers take the stage, is decidedly devoid of elected Republican leaders. Instead, singer Kid Rock and Ultimate Fighting Championship CEO Dana White will be speaking along with Hogan before Trump gives his nomination speech. And at the end of the day, with our leader up there, my hero, that gladiator, we're gonna bring America back together, one real American at a time, brother,\" Hogan said.\n\nHogan went on to compare Trump and his running mate, Hillbilly Elegy's J.D. Vance, to himself and a former ally. \"You know somethin', I've seen some great tag-teams in my time: Hulk Hogan and oooh yeah, the Macho Man Randy Savage,\" he said. \"But you know somethin'? I see the greatest tag-team of my life standing upon us, getting ready to straighten this country out for all the real Americans.\"\n\nLater, Hogan called the former president \"Donald Dick J. Trump\" for some reason. \"Even though you guys are real Americans, you better get ready, because when Donald Dick J. Trump becomes the president of the United States, all the real Americans are gonna be nicknamed Trumpites,\" he explained. \"Because all the Trumpites are gonna be runnin' wild for four years. So with the power of Donald J. Trump and all the Trumpites runnin' wild, America is gonna get back on track, like Donald J. Trump said: America is gonna be great again.\"\n\nThe most memorable moment in Hogan's speech came with an instantly-memeable (and mockable) visual cue: He ripped open his Hulk Hogan shirt to reveal a Trump-Vance 2024 top beneath it.\n\n\"I think about how Donald Trump, his family was compromised,\" he said. \"When I look out there and I see Donald Trump, I think about how his business was compromised. But what happened last week when they took a shot at my hero, and they tried to kill the next president of the United States, enough was enough! And I said, let Trumpamania run wild, brother. Let Trumpamania rule again. Let Trumpamania make America great again.\"\n\nSign up for Entertainment Weekly's free daily newsletter to get breaking TV news, exclusive first looks, recaps, reviews, interviews with your favorite stars, and more.\n\nHogan also argued that Trump is stronger than all of his former opponents in the ring, invoking some of the 45th president's most shameful moments as if they're prideful battle scars. \"Donald Trump is the toughest of them all,\" he said. \"They've thrown everything at Donald Trump -- all the investigations, the impeachments, the court cases -- and he's still standing and kicking their butts. You know, we never had it better than the Trump years.\"\n\nThe wrestler concluded his remarks by directly addressing a very strange set of viewers. \"All you criminals, all you low-lifes, all you scumbags, all you drug dealers, and all you crooked politicians need to answer one question, brother: Whatcha gonna do when Donald Trump and all the Trumpomaniacs run wild on you, brother?\" he posited. \"God bless you, and thank you.\"\n\nThe live-stream then cut to Trump smiling, pumping his fist, and even blowing a kiss to the wrestler.\n\nThe RNC has also heard speeches from Amber Rose, The wrestling legend initially took to the stage in a navy blazer and a T-shirt with a photo of himself holding the US flag and the caption \"real American.\" Minutes later, he pulled off the blazer and ripped his T-shirt to reveal a Trump-J.D. Vance tank top underneath, referencing the Republicans' nominees for president and vice-president.\n\nHogan gushed about his love of Trump, calling him his \"hero\" and a \"gladiator.\" The shirt-ripping stunt was timed to the part of his speech where he expressed outrage at the attempted assassination of Trump at a rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, last weekend.\n\n\"What happened last week when they took a shot at my hero and they tried to kill the next president of the United States? Enough was enough. Let Trump-a-mania run wild, brother. Let Trump-a-mania rule again. Let Trump-a-mania make America great again,\" he hollered, quoting Trump's campaign motto.\n\nHogan also accused the US political establishment of throwing \"investigations, impeachments, and court cases\" at Trump to undermine his public image, but said the former president \"is still kicking their butts.\"\n\nThe crowd's reaction to Hogan's performance was enthusiastic, while Trump himself was seen smiling and applauding the wrestler.\n\nTrump also addressed the RNC on Thursday night, in a speech he completely rewrote following the Butler shooting. He officially accepted the GOP nomination, vowing that \"four months from now, we will have an incredible victory, and we will begin the four greatest years in the history of our country.\"\n\nTrump has risen in most polls since the assassination attempt, and currently holds a four-point advantage over Democratic rival Joe Biden, according to an Emerson College survey published on Thursday. {"uri": "8232741821", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "03:05:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T03:05:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T03:04:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5215686559677124, "url": "https://freebeacon.com/author/stiles/america/trump-a-mania-celebs-honor-gop-nominee-in-overwhelming-display-of-star-power/", "title": "TRUMP-A-MANIA: Celebs Honor GOP Nominee in Overwhelming Display of Star Power", "body": "Hulk Hogan, Kid Rock, Dana White, the list goes on. Meanwhile, washed up actors are begging Joe Biden to quit.\n\nDonald Trump is crushing Joe Biden in the polls, but he's also on top when it comes to celebrity endorsements. The GOP's commanding star power was on full display Thursday night ahead of Trump's much anticipated primetime address amid reports that Biden could withdraw from the race as early as this weekend. (Keep fighting, Joe!)\n\nConsider this mind-blowing fact: Linda McMahon, the former Trump administration official and wife of professional wrestling pioneer Vince McMahon, was one of three convention speakers Thursday night who has been on the receiving end of a \"Stone Cold Stunner.\" (If you have to ask, you don't deserve to know.)\n\n\"Honestly incredible speaking lineup at the RNC,\" Semafor editor Max Tani wrote. \"Tucker Carlson opening up for the general manager for Trump's golf club, then we've got Kid Rock, Hulk Hogan, and Dana White.\"\n\nHulk Hogan, the professional wrestling icon and star of the 1996 feature film Santa with Muscles, whipped the convention crowd into a frenzy at the Fiserv Forum in Milwaukee. He instantly reminded viewers of his undisputed status as one of the greatest American entertainers to ever live.\n\n\"WHEN THEY TOOK A SHOT AT MY HERO, AND THEY TRIED TO KILL THE NEXT PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES, ENOUGH WAS ENOUGH, AND I SAID LET TRUMP-A-MANIA RUN WILD, BROTHER!\" The Hulk roared while tearing his shirt in half to reveal a Trump-Vance logo underneath. \"LET TRUMP-A-MANIA RULE AGAIN! LET TRUMP-A-MANIA MAKE AMERICAN GREAT AGAIN!\"\n\nIn addition to his illustrious professional career, Hogan is widely admired for his efforts to take down Gawker, the hipster gossip website whose former editor admitted in court that he would consider child porn \"newsworthy.\" Whereas George Clooney and other relatively uncharismatic liberal celebs have been begging President Joe Biden to step aside, Hogan offered his full-throated endorsement of the Republican nominee.\n\n\"Over my career, I've been in the ring with some of the biggest, some of the baddest dudes on the planet, and I've squared off against warriors,\" Hogan said. \"Donald Trump is the toughest of them all.\"\n\nThe arena sizzled with star power. The convention band, Nashville-based Sixwire, banged out hit after hit. Attendees saw a video montage of Trump's long history of cultivating friendships with celebrities such as Oprah Winfrey and fat Al Sharpton. Musical legend Kid Rock took the stage and echoed Trump's now iconic chant of \"fight, fight,\" seconds after surviving an assassination, while performing his hit song, \"Cowboy.\" UFC chief executive Dana White introduced the speaker everyone had come to see, the \"toughest man\" he's ever met, the ultimate celebrity: Donald Trump.\n\nEven liberal journalists could feel the excitement. \"The last time I was at a convention that felt like this was Obama 2008,\" CNN analyst Van Jones said. \"There's something happening.\" His colleague Scott Jennings concurred. \"This is a vibes election,\" he More info\n\nMelania Trump revealed what she really thought at the Republican National Convention after she struggled to control her facial expression.\n\nThe former first lady accompanied husband Donald Trump, 78, as he accepted the GOP nomination at the event in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, on Thursday (July 18) and gave a passionate speech. The gathering saw him speak out publicly for the first time since he survived an assassination attempt at a Pennsylvania rally which saw him sustain an injury to the ear.\n\nWWE icon Hulk Hogan and musician Kid Rock were among the celebrity attendees to the event - Kid Rock even performed at the event. However it seemed Melania wasn't keen on the All Summer Long singer's set.\n\nPosting a video of the moment to X (formerly Twitter) one critic said: \"Melania Trump trying not to laugh at Kid Rock is the funniest thing I've ever seen.\"\n\nAnother added: \"He's an acquired taste.\" Someone else echoed the sentiment, adding: \"It is difficult not to laugh at him, I understand her struggle.\"\n\nA third agreed: \"I don't blame her,\" while another said they found the situation \"so funny.\"\n\nWWE star Hulk Hogan, real name Terry Gene Bollea, also made waves at the convention as he ripped off his shirt on stage. He went on to dub Trump a \"hero\" and condemn his would-be killer.\n\n\"What happened last week... when they took a shot at my hero... The Republican nominee survived the incident with a pierced ear while two additional people were injured.\n\nFirefighter Corey Comperatore died during the attack.
